nice little turkish/middle eastern byob joint, appears like a newer place. i came here at about four o'clock and was still offered their lunch menu, and it was quite a deal. the falafel was great, served with what tasted like straight tahini rather than hummus, and the lamb was excellent as well, all meat not fatty or 90% gristle. service disappeared for a while but i was on a picnic bench outside of the regular seating area, so i'll withhold judgment for now. parking seems to be rather limited but that can't be helped.

while i'm on my orange chicken reviews, i'll do this one. i've dined in lao sze chuan some time ago with my husband and yelp friends, a mini uye, remember those? anyhow, we left that time unimpressed, my husband even less so than me. i've done a few take outs since then and it was okay, not bad not good, nothing to write about, so i didn't review. well, this time, it wasn't edible. hey, maybe it's me, maybe orange chicken is supposed to have chicken that tastes like fatty, bready pieces. i really wonder how they make it? i like to cook a lot and all i can think of if i were trying to duplicate this, i'd chop up the chicken pieces with skin on add the breading, mix then scoop and roll out pieces and fry them, then dump sauce on them. the sauce was good, but the chicken? i bit into one piece and grabbed a napkin to dispose of it. i cut four more pieces in half and it didn't look like solid pieces of meat. at that point i packed it all up and walked it outside to my trash can. i know this place has a following, and that's fine, i won't be one of them, i'm sure they're okay with that. i do commend them for their sending meals to hospital workers during this time of covid. so if you're a fan of something they make, support them. i did see the owner being interviewed on the news and his heart is in the right place.
steamed potstickers. spicy cabbage. heaven. certainly some valid complaints about the service but the food is always banging.

drawn to this james beard winner my first time in chicago 3 years ago, and now i live here and still eating this from time to time especially during this pandemic. standard dishes such as dry chili chicken and green beans still remain delicious. i think this place still satiates hungry customers desiring standard szechuan dishes with the understanding that these dishes albeit delicious come at an extra price compared to normal. for the extra grease/price but still at appropriate saltiness and taste, i recommend the dry chili chicken. i also recommend the green beans to help relieve any post constipation. and i recommend this during covid times because why not support small asian businesses?

lao sze chuan is one of those frustrating restaurants that uses high quality ingredients, but falls short of making delicious meals. not only that, but they're also relatively expensive. i've been to all three locations and this review applies across the board. in fact, i may just copy and paste. lbvs. i'll keep it simple (i.e.americanized : |) when ordering chinese food. i know, i know. . please don't judge me. orange chicken, beef and broccoli, fried rice and egg rolls. . that rounds out a typical order for me. i was tempted to rate 2 stars, but they aren't that bad. a solid 3, not a tenth of a star more.

wasn't sure if i was imagining that my leftovers on my plate were not the same (amount) as they placed in the doggy bag until our most recent visit. my sister, mother and i visited your restaurant many times and have noticed a trend. recently, we all had leftovers that the waitress insisted (i stress insisted) on placing the leftovers in the doggy bag herself. so we let her. the next day, we all met up and spoke of the restaurant. we all noticed that we didn't have all of the leftovers in our take home bags. so we all agreed that they took some our food before we left. unbelievable. haven't been there since and will never go back.

i ordered delivery at a sunday night. the food was not very fresh. the spicy rabbits was a little bit dry and not flavorful. the spicy chicken was comparable much better. i haven't visited this place in person but i assume they would provide similar quality of food.
delicious food! ordered for delivery last night. great customer service. the noodles and rice had so much flavor. i choose medium heat which was more than plenty. i highly recommend
our favorite chinese restaurant in the city and definitely the best location. the mapo tofu and string beans are a must! the owner tommy is a sweetheart and hangs around on weekends

a friend insisted on ordering carry out from here last night: 201 vegetarian shanghai spring rolls just okay. 563 chef's special dry chili chicken still not as good as it used to be. it's missing a flavor and was super oily today. 805 spicy don don noodles the noodles were good and still chewy, but there wasn't enough sauce. 7055 house special vegetable fried rice very bland and not mixed well. there were clumps of white rice throughout. and where were the vegetables? just some frozen peas and carrots? 808 spicy szechuan wonton these were the worst spicy szechuan wontons i have ever had. very bland and dry, not enough sauce or spice. these were disgusting. tasted like dried up meatballs wrapped in soggy wonton. i would never order this again. the one star review is for this: i was early for picking up the order, so it wasn't ready yet. while i was waiting, i saw a server handle money, touch the pos ordering screen and then sort through the chopsticks by touching the tips! she also handled the plates being served to customers. gross. never dining in for sure.

chinatown is crowded with dozens of restaurants and options many that are of great quality. it's competitive place and lao sze chuan just hasn't kept up with the times. especially when it comes to authentic cuisine but also in general. the quality of the dishes that come out are a coin toss with some too salty, some strangely sweet, others perfect and some completely unseasoned. the place definitely is rich in chinatown's history but it's little more than that at this point.

one of my favorite spots in chinatown! favorite dishes definitely include the crispy shrimp in lemon sauce, as well as the cashew chicken and the orange beef tenderloin. you really can't go wrong with anything on the menu. if you're feeling adventurous try the boiled fresh frog in spicy szechuan sauce. maybe if you're lucky, my favorite host tommy the hype man will show you a demonstration with his ceremonial blade. this place is worth checking out whether you're visiting chicago or you're a native!
this is best resturant at chinatown. too frienly owner , perfect service and clean resturant. food? they are crazy delicious.
good chinese cuisine,good ambience and good service.had fish in schezwan sauce,cumin lamb,schezwan potstickers.all were good! d best was dan dan noodles! good place to go eat in cold weather!

man, i've always loved this place. from their signature dry chili chicken to the cumin lamb and fish in szechuan sauce. the flavor and spiciness just can't be beat. it's one of my favorites. but my last experience here was so disappointing. it's a shame. i had made a reservation for 9 on a saturday night and when we arrived, the waiter was confused and overwhelmed because he's supposed to only have two parties up here and ours was the third party. furthermore, and this is the most disappointing part, our food took forever to come out and it came out at extremely spread out times. it took over an hour to get the order of garlic peapod leaves. and the chili chicken, mongolian beef, chicken in sze chuan sauce, napo tofu, and cumin lamb all came about 15 minutes apart. they offered no apology or compensation for this disappointing meal, and every time we asked the waiter for anything he acted like we had just asked the world of him. lao sze chuan, learn how to serve parties during peak dinner time!

i feel conflicted about this place. food is great, but service is questionable. food: i ordered the mapo tofu. the flavor was excellent. the tofu was just soft enough for the dish to make it a great meal. paired with a bowl of rice, this was a fulfilling dinner. service: i entered in and was confused about how to get seated. the staff was super busy and i was redirected to a man in the front who i didn't see before. he put me at one of the front tables. waiting to order took a while. having the one dish served also took a long time. staff is nice when you interact with them, but service is super slow. price: a little bit more expensive than other places, but the portion size was not bad at all. ambiance: pretty modern for a chinese restaurant. inside is clean and walls are pretty aesthetic. overall, the food is great and the portion size is reasonable for the price you are paying. my only concern is the service it's super slow. my experience could be different from yours, so still give it a try!

never ever order delivery from this place. i called the restaurant after the order was late. told 15 min away. waited another hour. called again. told 15 min. waited another hour for them to arrive. over 3 hours to get delivered from time of order placement. shit happens. but come on. that's blatant lying and ridiculous.

wow! i'm in love with the spicy chili chicken. i am usually not a fan of super spicy food, but there is something about this spicy chili chicken that i can't have enough of. it's like the lay's potatoes chip. you can't just eat one. the chicken is crispy, spicy and filled with peppers in a very good way. i really can't stop eating it. the szechuan string beans is a very nice compliment to the chicken. those were their top two best selling dishes and it did not disappoint at all. i highly recommend both. i will definitely be back.

horrible service! i don't care how good the food is. i am still in shock at how awful we were treated! didn't help that regulars who were clearly more familiar were being treated far better right in front of us!
always eating. we head here every year for a big dinner. my buddy tommy always takes good care of us, and the food is great.

this place is a staple in chinatown to satisfy that spicy crave! i was craving some spicy wontons this past weekend and was glad to find that lao sze chuan was open until 11pm. while browsing the menu, we were served some spicy picked cabbage which definitely had quite a kick to it. we got the szechuan wontons, fish fillet in black bean sauce, and napa cabbage in wine sauce. all our food came out at once, and i really liked everything, but wished the wontons were spicier. the napa was also nice and crunchy, which i looved. portions were also quite large. we ended up taking back about a third of our food. i don't end up coming here much because there are other places in chinatown that serve similar food for cheaper prices, but it's a classic restaurant that i wouldn't mind recommending to others.

visiting this restaurant last night. feel soooo disappointed. we ordered 7 dishes for 3 of us. beef soup used pig fat trying to enhance the flavor but gross. compliment cold dishes was full of msg. i understand chinese food always put msg but i don't understand why need to put sooo much. xiaolongbao just wrapped a meat ball no tender texture. 2 vegetable dishes used pig lard again. fish dishes is the only one passed even with tons of msg.
honestly the worst chinese food i have had in the city. the rice noodles were covered in a seasoning that was horrible and hard to even choke down.

to be honest, the food are good. but the service are very bad, and it's not about the waiter or the waitress there, it's about the manager who named tommy, he's very rude and very creepy, he have very bad attitude, and i don't know what is means that happened to me there, but i just want to share with you guys. when i was eating there, he standing beside of my table, pretending he's on phone, and he's camera are against to me, then the light was flashing. i feel very wired and offended. but it's my fault that i didn't took any actions on that, i should've just call the police and say something. for that, i will never go back to that restaurant again.

came in during a food tour with chicago food plant chinatown adventure. the place was a tad small, but it seems like a lot of the places in chinatown are like that. we tried a variety of dishes, eggplant, chili chicken, and i believe the same kind of chicken just not as spicy. to start off with at the table there was 2 plates one with pickled cabbage, but beware because it had a good spicy kick to it and then peppercorns. now the peppercorns was just a weird experience. at first your mouth tasted the bitterness of the peppercorn, but after a couple seconds you get this lemon/citrus taste that lingers in the back of your throat and honestly makes it kind of hard to drink water or just get the flavor out in general! for the food it was okay, definitely for people who can enjoy and handle a spicier palate. everything for me was too spicy (except for the non spicy chili chicken which even then still had a kick). if you like spicy come here! if not then i would stay away.

staff is very friendly. they always remember my brother and i. they remember what we order. we always get the mapo tofu and tony's chicken. the staff always give a good amount of rice too. i would recommend it.

kept reoccurring the same charge. different day. when i called , the host kept stuttering and saying she would need to contact that manager to get resolved. never asked for my contact number, never asked for the amount, never asked for anything. just kept stuttering and said she was going to let her manager know. ummm. yea i have a feeling they are doing it to multiple people . keep an eye out for double charges different days.

lao size chuan a chicago joint that's like no other tommy treat my young slime andy like a kardashian he did nothing and got all the attention i mean tommy gave him ff a fan and fortune cookies the food and service
the best pork fried rice i have ever had. the szechuan was very spicy but oh so good.

this l.a. boy has his pick of the chinese food litter just about 20 miles east of me in the san gabriel valley. the abundance of fantastic chinese food from every province in china is at my door step. so, my first night here in chicago visiting my 3 and 4 sons, they took me for this really wonderful dinner here at lao sze chuan. first off, we walked into this restaurant at 10:00 p.m. when most places in l.a. are already mopping the floors and a closed sign is hung on the door vive la difference! lao sze had family's, lovers, rockers, rappers and locals all eating this peppery cuisine (at this late hour) which means this place was buzzing. the authenticity of their food rivaled my coveted sichuan impressions back home in arcadia, ca. here at lao sze they started us off by giving you a freebie spicey cabbage bowl that could be the best thing they serve. then we ordered: won ton soup theirs is this dark flavor bomb of a soup.i loved it yu shiang pork delectable and addictive chili eggplant spicey with a mellow burn orange chicken just sweet enough to put out the fire from the previous three dishes some tsing tao beers and these nice people here at lao sze absolutely aced this dinner. i've been to this restaurant several times before, but on this evening i actually paid attention to the food and i was dutifully rewarded!

fake sze chuan ! this place is a shame. we ordered xiaolongbao and it turned out it's from the kind of frozen packages you get from super market. the traditional three pepper chicken is deep fried chicken, very greasy and heavy, not at all the way this traditional dish should be. the worst is the green pepper beef, it's way of cooking is ridiculous and taste is terrible.

waited approximately 30 min for a table. when a table finally became available, the waiter seated a larger party who had just walked in. she didn't even ask us if we would mind. when we protested, she simply gave what are you going to do about it attitude. i get the motive / economics but not a good way to run a restaurant. will never dine here again.

this chinatown resturant specializss in schezwan chinese food. it does not take reservations (i heard that their other location does). comfortable seating, except for the strange clear plastic chairs they use. we had tony's chicken with three chilis. it was very good and i would order it again . but is deep fried with a sweet glazing so is not very healthy. we also had the the beef with cumin which would have been great except it was standing in oil (see picture). we had to ask for napkins to soak up some of the grease before we could eat it. (thus it was not a 5 star meal).
do not go to this place to waste your time and money. it is fast but food is lackluster. and it is not cheap. years ago was better. a restaurant in coasting mode. stay away.

despite not being a chicago local, i feel compelled to yelp lao sze chuan and share my story below. this restaurant was already on my radar before coming on a week trip to the city. i had seen it on anthony bourdain's travel show, and one of my chinese students ate here recently and recommended it. we decided to order take out from the chinatown location because 1. prices are a little cheaper than the flagship on michigan ave and 2. the chinatown menu is bigger. also, delivery was available to our address. so, funny story. they day we're planning to order take out, my husband and i are sitting in the food court of the north bridge shops, eating salads at a table just outside yet another location of the restaurant inside the mall. a man came out talking with a woman, and i overheard her call him tony. now, i've been scrolling the menu online already that day and had seen a bunch of tony's special dishes listed. i decide to be bold and interrupt, asking if he was the tony? indeed, it was the owner/chef himself. he was so nice and spent time talking to us about the menu when we told him we were getting food that night. he answered my questions about the differences between a couple chicken dishes and some eggplant options (they got, like, 8 eggplant dishes which is pretty serious). tony says, a lot of people have garlic eggplant, but i'm the only one who makes spicy eggplant with ground pork. onto the food: we ordered the signature dry spice chicken. i was hesitant to order this dish because i had it previously at a well regarded restaurant in sf chinatown, and it was dry, bland, and consisted mostly of the peppers themselves (so many that we took a picture of all that were left after we ate the chicken). tony's version was amazing. really spicy, great sauce, moist chicken. (i loved it so much i actually sucked on some of the peppers themselves. warning: you might want to consider this is not going to be the best idea later on, but i still say it was worth it.) we got the eggplant with pork. how could we not? which was also fantastic. i also recommend the szechuan wontons, and we rounded out the meal with peapod sprouts (i always love those). in short, a great szechuan chinese experience. last thing we talked about with tony. he is thinking of opening a restaurant in cambridge (ma). please, please open a restaurant in the boston area. we will eat there all the time! chicago, you guys are lucky.

jeez, what happened to this place. i started to eat my lackluster meal when i saw a bug inside my daughters cup, i looked over at my wife to tell her when i noticed another bug of a different species. when i looked down at my plate saw another live bug. im now under the realization that there are insects everywhere. i call the over to a waiter who calmly brushes them away. i ask to see a manager who comes over to the table to look and says she sees no other live bugs and only points at tye dead ones on the window sill. i refuse to pay as i had only took 2 bites of the phone. she tells me i have to pay because she doesn't see live bugs. i pull out my camera and show her the pictures. suddenly its ok to not pay. horrible sanitary conditions

one of the best chinese restaurants i have been following in chicago. we went for lunch , it was very busy but we didn't have to wait for long to get seated. the place is small so can get crowded and noisy sometimes , but it didn't quite matter much to me since the food was so so so good . we loved whatever we orders , but for me the showstopper was the lalala chicken . such a perfect blend of that szechuan taste and it's spice. i had been craving for this since so long and now i know where to go to when i am in chicago. dont miss their chef's special dry chilli chicken as well , they are totally mind blowing. since we were very excited to find this location, we think we ordered quite much . the portion of the food were also large and since we were only a group of two, it was also enough for us for our dinner at home later that day !

located at the edge of the chinese market area, this relatively small but pleasant restaurant caught our eye while searching for a late dinner location in chinatown. we were able to park in the street right out front (metered parking) and we were seated immediately and offered hot tea. overall, the extensive menu and vibe of the establishment were appealing, and authentic enough while still having favorites like crab rangoon, spring rolls, and vegetable fried rice on the menu. everything was very fresh and tasty, and service was prompt and very pleasant. we enjoyed a quiet, reasonably priced late dinner before settling into our hotel for the night. i would definitely recommend this restaurant for a friendly, low intensity dinner.

one of my favorite places for good, spicy chinese food. highly recommend. the dry chili chicken green beans, fried bread, and orange beef are my favorites. can't go wrong with any dumplings or pot stickers.

this is probably one of my favorite places in chinatown. i've been coming here with my family since i have been young and the taste has not changed one bit. came here a couple days ago with my boyfriend and ordered the twice cooked pork and the crispy lemon shrimp. since we're regulars here, we ordered as soon as we sat down. the pork is always cooked to a nice crisp and juicy taste, soaking up all of the sauce. the shrimp is nice and crispy and just melts in your mouth. you really can't go wrong ordering twice cooked pork and crispy lemon shrimp here. the staff is always super friendly and will provide whatever you ask. they aren't always the most attentive, but who goes to chinatown for good service? all you have to do is ask and you'll get it. they do charge a dollar or two per rice that you ask, but you get unlimited refills so that's a plus. by the time we asked for the check, the server asked, leaving already? to our surprise it had only been 20 minutes since we had gotten there and spent time eating. i can attest that the food does come out and an unbelievably fast rate and they are not there to waste your time. not a fast food restaurant but the food comes out just as fast. definitely would recommend coming to this place and checking it out. they do have multiple locations outside of chinatown, but i do feel that the chinatown location does have the best taste and portion size of all the other chicago locations that i've been to.

my friend and i came for dinner earlier second time food is amazing, large portions and really nice and efficient staff. tommy (owner? mod?) made my night as he turned off the lights and guided a segmented orange with a birthday candle (and a flash light!) to a guest celebrating. as we walked out he shook our hands and thanked us for coming. get the pork pot stickers, dry chili chicken, and sichuan eggplant. so good. complementary kimchi is bomb too and byob.

you are better off at chinese buffet. we asked the server for water at least 4 times and they told us their chief cut his hand and couldn't serve us water. when there's 4 people around just doing nothing. also they're not helpful at explaining to you how the menu works either. we ordered house special fry rice and it was really spicy for the kids. we asked them why it's so spicy and they said it's because there's 3 pepper on the menu showing you how spicy it is. wish they can better explain their menu when we told them it's our first time eating there. do not go here. you'll set yourself up for disappointment!

was staying at a nearby hotel in chicago and read the good reviews so got takeout! used uber eats to get it. was very happy with the food! the vegetable fried rice was spicy and yummy and they give a lot of it! i could eat it by itself. the chili chicken and sesame chicken were great too! you can pick spicy levels which is nice. good size portions too!

see the pic, the food was bad. barely any meat in the noodles that were supposed to be beef lo mein, i got pepper flavored noodles with barely any meat. the general tso chicken was decent but again, barely any meat about 90% breading. won't be ordering from here again based on food quality.
found a bunch of eggshells and an expiration sticker tag in my food. do not recommend.
we went in with a large group and they seated us upstairs. i was pleasantly surprised by the vegetarian options. vegetables, tofu, rice was perfect!

my friend and i were looking to branch out from our normal chinatown spots and were recommended this restaurant by multiple friends. i was a bit apprehensive since i know that szechuan can be rather spicy and my spice tolerance is relatively low. the cabbage brought to the table with the drinks was the spiciest thing that i ate, but it was pretty manageable. we started with spring rolls that were served with a plum and mustard sauce and then both got noodle dishes for our main courses. i got the combination pan fried noodles, and my friend got the vegetable lo mein. i wasn't sure what to expect from the dish, but it seemed like a pretty standard noodle and meat dish. the sauce was a bit bland but had a good flavor. the real star of the dish was the mushrooms, which really stood out from the other vegetables and meat. i think next time i'd like to try a more traditional szechuan dish to get the whole experience.
food was ok. only their dry rub chili chicken was really good. too many vegetables in the entrees. service was terrible. guy at the front who is sort of the hostess screaming is really uncomfortable.

we arrived at a very busy time and they asked us to enter through the upstairs door instead of the 1st level. that door was locked and we waited in the cold for 10 minutes before going back and asking to be let in. after another 5 minutes someone finally came and unlocked the door. the food portions are generous and served family style. unfortunately, we were not sharing out of preference. we chose this restaurant because they have very spicy options and they were delicious. we had some issues since the dishes were all served at very different times, and the final dish was extremely delayed. everyone else had finished eating before our friend had even started.

enjoyed this place so much. the employees were great people and the food was even better. authentic chinese and great portion sizes. from the spicy cabbage, sesame chicken, free refills on steamed rice, and the dumplings! everything was incredible!
i ordered the chef's dry rub chili chicken and it was a tub of bone. they wouldn't even take it back and replace my order of bones with a new one.
craving for spicy chinese? go get the chef's special dry chilly chicken. as a matter of fact i might go get some right now.

this is my first negative review. this place was a huge disappointment! the food was disaster. we ordered a pork dish (it was called pork with garlic sauce or something). the shredded pork has already gone bad! we got food poisoning after having the spoiled pork. wish i could give it 0 stars. will never come back!

looooove this place. the food here is extremely addicting (possible because of the msg, which i'm totally fine with). you gotta do family style because the portions are large and how else are you gonna try all the wonderful dishes they have to offer? my/my family's favorites (yes, a lot of these are salty and fried so don't pick these if you're trying to eat healthy): szechuan string beans dry chili chicken spicy veggie fried rice salt and pepper shrimp (we request it with no shell so it's easier to eat) cumin lamb house special spicy sole filet we get the szechuan string beans and salt and pepper shrimp literally every single time we've been here. i even like the chili oil cabbage that they put on your table when you're seated because what doesn't taste good in chili oil? oh yeah don't forget to get a validated parking ticket from them if you parked in one of those big lots on wentworth!
i killed a cockroach on our table halfway through the meal! it made it's way from the kitchen to our table, i'm thinking on the bottom of one of the plates we were given!

pros: fast service, large menu with several options including hot pot, great presentation of food, good location in the chinatown square strip mall. cons: although good flavor, both main dishes were waaayyy too salty. i think i might return again, but will have to tell them to notify chef, easy on the salt! i've been here a total of 3x, first time food was excellent, 2nd time it was average at best, 3rd time, wasn't edible in my opinion because of the high sodium content. i wish the chef or chefs could be more consistent with their cooking styles because i really want to like this place, but it is summing up to be a hit or miss spot for me.

great authentic szechuanese food in the heart of chinatown. i always get the chili chicken with peppercorns and the spicy green beans when i visit. the chicken is crispy but not drenched in oil and the green beans are crisp, garlicky, with a hint of spice. the service may be a little brusque and may seem unapproachable for non chinese people but rest assured that the food is worth a visit.

horrible experience. menu states that mapo tofu is a vegetarian dish but it is not , i found meat in my dish . my son ordered chicken and he found ball of hair in his dish . we all left after few bites of our food , this place is not for vegetarian , folks with food allergy needs to be super careful before stepping in to this restaurant.

oh wow what can i say about this place. even though i was born in northeastern china, i grew up eating szechuan cuisine and anything spicy (sadly my spice tolerance went down a bit since starting college). every time my family goes to the city we would stop at lao sze chuan because we love the food so much. granted, the restaurant is a bit cramped and the tables are covered with disposable table clothes, so it might be less glamorous than the michigan avenue one (which i've also been to and it's also very good!) but i always look at this chinatown one with nostalgia and love. we almost always get the same 4 dishes while we're here (see images), and we save the broth/gravy from the szechuan beef to make mapo tofu when we get home. if you're in chinatown and have a decent spice tolerance, this is hands down my favorite choice.

with exception of the tea smoked duck (which was delicious), everything else we ordered was awful. disgusting. tasteless, oily. i highly recommend minghin instead as the quality of their cooking and ingredients are always good. definitely do not order the desserts. holy crap, i've never had worse chinese desserts. the little rice balls should be soft and filled with sweet black sesame, not sugar wrapped in thick, leathery rice paste. there was no red bean, lotus nut, and various other typical ingredients in the steamed sweet rice. the waitress apologized saying these were not made in house. they don't need to be, but they should be made correctly if they are putting this stuff on the menu.
been going here for years. great portion size and high quality food. not unreasonable for the price and have a ton of options.
love their spicy foods great service and good lunch place for winter. the atmosphere is very busy and makes me feel like home.

the menu was a little intimidating at first with how many options and things i wasn't sure about but i have to say it was amazing! the staff was very friendly and service was quick. i will certainly be back. just go in take a seat take some time to read the menu, whatever you order won't disappoint you!

if you only order one thing make sure it's the string beans! they were absolutely lovely in every way. we also had the dry chili chicken, mapo tofu which were good, but i felt they were not as spicy as i wanted.
being late for 3 hours!forgot to add spice to my order! extremely bad! and slow!the app wants a long long long log long review. stupidapp

never again. such a love/hate relationship with lao sze chuan. the food is fantastic but the restaurant is a hot mess. terrible service and every time i have order delivery it has been incredibly late, which since they have a 6.00 delivery charge, is unacceptable

wow! what a delicious meal! my book club shared a few dishes pot stickers, combination fried rice, orange beef tenderloin (!), sweet and sour chicken, and cashew shrimp, along with jasmine tea. everything was tender, tasty, and abundant enough to take 1/2 home. loved it and can't wait to return!

showed up here for an early lunch with my sister, in need of a spicy food fix. we were looking for a particular szechuan fish entree that i've had several other places: mild fish fillets in a flaming hot broth, often with some kind of vegetable, and buried in chili peppers. the problem is that it seems to go by a different name in every restaurant. i gave a description to our waitress her english and my chinese were both pretty minimal but she got the right thing to us, 437 chef's special sole fish fillet with tofu. it had the right combo of ma (numbing) and la (spicy) but was oddly lacking salt. we were able to rescue it with the salt shaker on the table. stir fried green beans (not spicy) and cumin lamb (medium zing), both very good, rounded out the meal. we had enough leftovers for a couple meals later. price was reasonable and service was good better than the terse treatment common in many chinese restaurants.

this place was a real disappointment. i love szechuan food, but this place completely missed the mark. food is spicy, but there's no real flavor. it's also extremely greasy. i ordered rice noodles with ground pork and it turned out to be a heap of glass noodles with a tiny bit of pork swimming in chili oil. glass noodles is completely different from rice noodles. they also gouge you in all chinese restaurants i have been to, meat or vegetable dishes come with a serving of rice. this place charged 14 for my terrible dish (1 more thsn stated in the menu) and then added 1 for a small bowl of rice which they served together with the dish. will never come back, especially because there are so many other good restaurants in this stretch.

this use to be our favorite restaurant for take out and delivery. but tonight we called to find out why it was taking over 1 hour and 40 minutes for our delivery. the lady who answered the phone shouted at me we are busy, 20 more minutes! and then hung up on me. i was going to offer to pick the food up if it hadn't left the restaurant, but i couldn't even offer that because she hung up on me. i called grubhub cancelled our order and called phoenix chinese and placed my new order with them. very different experience. customer service is everything in the restaurant business. it doesn't matter how good your food is. people will stop coming if you forget how to treat your customers with some respect.

haven't been to this place for a long time. this locations food quality is inferior than the one at evanston. brought my coworkers to this place for the first time because it's closer to work. very disappointed at their szechuan string beans beans are so over grown that you can hardly chew on it. three cups chicken is too sweet. things are just not the right flavor as the other locations.

we walked in this place a little before 10:00 pm, so it was not real busy. the service was fine. i read some of the reviews after we ate and i can see that some people thought the place was dirty and the service poor. i guess i could see that. it certainly was not as clean and sparkly as other places we ate at on our chicago trip and there was some yelling from the kitchen. so what? i f you care about that dont eat here. if you like good spicy food give it a try. we had the chefs special chicken and the szechuan chicken. both excellent! t he spicy pickled cabbage was awesome. hot! but good. it was too much food for us at that time if night. but i hated seeing it go to waste. we bagged it up and gave it away to the first homeless we saw. food was 5 stars. loved it. just dont expect 5 star treatment and cleanleness. on a side note we went to two other higher rated places close by both closed at 10:00 both turned us down at 9:45 or so.

very good chinese food in the heart of chinatown square. we took the water taxi down to chinatown to get lunch and tried lao sze chuan on a recommendation. the time on the door says they open at 10:30 but upon entering we were told it was not opening until 11. they brink a spicy cabbage plate to the table gratis to start. we tried the spring rolls (good), the crab rangoon (very good), and the orange chicken (a bit syrupy), and chef's spicy chicken (which was fabulous). it was plenty of food and the prices were reasonable. one note of caution, the yelp deal for free spring rolls is tricky. when we tried to use the coupon she wanted to bring us two more for free and charge us for the ones we had ordered and instructed us that you have show it up front because of the computer. she checked with a manager on her own accord and fixed it however. good food and worth a stop when you are in chinatown.
delicious spot in chinatown, easy and delicious vegetarian options including a really surprising potato dish i'm still thinking about years later!

this is more authentic place than rest of its chain in chicago. i have been to their restaurants located in north side and downtown, and i must say, it was just average. if you ever want to try the real authentic one do visit one in chinatown. i loved them.
one of my fav chinese restaurants in town. the dried chilly chicken and cumin lamb was so good. price bit on the higher side but the food was great!

it was a small restaurant with the owner walking around. service was very slow, food was spicy and good. it wasn't great though. chinatown chicago has become so modernized that it lost some authenticity. i wouldn't go here again with my family. but if you love spicy food. it's where to go.

food was really tasty. my friend and i were both in gastric distress that night and the following morning. not sure which of the 6 dishes we ordered did that. i'd pass and try one of the other thousand place in the area before returning.

1 st time here and went with a couple of my friends. my friend didn't like what she ordered and she asked the waitress to see if she could get something else and the waitress said that she couldn't and that she had to pay for her meal even tho if she didn't like it. i thought it was totally rude! will not visit ever again
to long yo wait for the menu, food not as tasty , thr servers cant understand our orders

definitely not five star dining and service, but they get the job done! we absolutely love spicy food so we always order the mapo tofu, house special sole fish fillet(way better than the boiled/soupy version), and the dry chili string beans with loads of rice to eat family style. we sometimes order the pork and bamboo shoots when we need a break from all the heat. these four dishes are a godsend! words cannot express how spicy/savory/delicious these items are. just try them! skip the orange chicken, beef broccoli, walnut shrimp, hot pot, dumplings, etc. they're known for szechuan cuisine lots of chili oil, peppers, peppercorn, garlic. you'll be disappointed if you stray too far. as for service, they take your order, refill your water and give you a check pretty simple. definitely don't be afraid to wave someone down or go up to the counter when you need something. the second owner, i believe his name is tony/tommy, is super friendly and quite a character. they usually have extra seating upstairs when it's too busy. if that's not open, you'll just have to wait outside until they call you. there's a parking lot but it can get full during rush lunch/dinner time.

the service was next to nonexistent. we got seated and our order taken and then completely ignored; to be fair, none of the servers were rude though.the dishes were tasty, but all were basically swimming in a bowl of chili oil.

this was probably one of the worst places i've been to. actually probably the worst. go spend your money elsewhere. we came in around 9pm. they told us to sit in a temporary table while we wait for another table to clear up when the restaurant was pretty much all open. they were trying to get the other people to leave by clearing up their table but that made us feel very uncomfortable. we just sat there confused as to why they couldn't sit as somewhere permanently. we had to ask ourselves to sit somewhere else. this was already our cue to leave but unfortunately we didn't. we ordered the ayce hot pot which was 18.95 per person. it's on the last page which was another hint that we shouldn't have got it. the broth was super plain. the dipping sauce was store bought. the seafood was frozen and looked rotten. the meat looked okay but the meat was hard to chew. the dude didn't even give us a bowl and spoon until we asked. he wasn't good at english, which was understandable, but it was more of the fact that he didn't know what was available. honestly i didn't want to eat anymore because the food was just sad. everything that could go wrong went wrong. the waiters were nice but they didn't know what was happening. to even put some more salt on our wounds, they included around ~18% gratuity with a table of 5. wish there were more heads up to this. my heart is crying. i love supporting small businesses, very tolerant of places, but this place spells no all across.

for being the best chinese food in the usa this place was mediocre at best. we were on a mission to find dumplings, although they had a very limited assortment. the best part was the little plate of cabbage with chili oil they brought at the beginning of the meal. beyond that, the dumplings, orange chicken, and mapo tofu were all much less flavorful than we were hoping.

i can't believe i haven't reviewed this place yet but honestly, this is my favorite chinese restaurant in chinatown. if you haven't had szechuan style food you are not living yet. it's a combination of spice, depth of flavor that can only be described as umami is incredible. i always get the dry chili chicken, twice cooked pork, szechuan string beans (ask for spicy and add ground pork to it), dan dan noodles, boiled beef or fish. those you cannot go wrong. the only dish i didn't love was tony's spice chicken which tasted like americanized panda express style chinese food. avoid unless you like that stuff. they have lunch specials which really make this worth going to. i wish i lived closer otherwise would break the bank for me. oh also they validate parking there.

some of the best chinese food i've ever eaten but seriously you must go to the chinatown location it's not the same at the other location they're ok for lunch but this is the bomb for dinner the curry lamb is so tender it practically melts in your mouth the seafood platter is so clean and buttery and the veggies are just barely steamed so still crisp but palatable eat it while hot once the sauce cools the flavor profile changes slightly had a friend in town who had never eaten duck. so got the crispy duck she is hooked and i thought it was perfectly cooked so damn yummy

they have a few good dishes, but the quality is not as good as the original downtown. also, service is just terrible. it is frustrating to have the kitchen constantly decide to close 15 20 minutes earlier than the official cut off time. i've actually been told on the phone that the kitchen last call is not for another 15 minutes, but they aren't taking my order regardless. if you don't want to take orders during your normal operating hours, maybe close up shop and leave evanston.

lychee tini! now that i have you wanting an exotic martini.let's talk about food. the crispy shrimp with lemon sauce is one if my favorite dishes here. i've also had a nice chilean sea bass in a light sauce with vegetables, but it had some good sized bones in it. the soups are great here too. the spicy cabbage slaw they give you as an appetizer was way too spicy for me. but to be fair, my spice reference is little to none! and yes, the lycheetini drink is so delicious and one i've tried to duplicate at home. however, mine have not been as good or as potent as they are here. beware of this delicious, addicting and potent concoction. my experience with the staff here, especially those at the bar, has been nothing but positive. i've even waited here at this bar, and enjoyed a drink, while in line for a table at the purple pig. i do agree with a previous review that i found the bathroom here to be neglected and dirty, which can be very unappetizing if you think about it. but i will still keep coming back for the delicious food and drink and the convenient location on mi ave.

i came with my family about an hour before the dinner rush. it took forever to get taken care of. i was ready to go in the back and get my own tea and cook my own food. a table that came in way after us got the appetizer and drinks before we did.the waitress said she was coming but then she took forever and never even gave us the cabbage appetizer that everyone else received. when it came to ordering, the waitress kept trying to talk us out of ordering all the food we wanted. i can read, and i can see that it says spicy, so let me order what i want. when we get the food there is zero spice to it.it looks like all those chilies were just for decoration. you know when you order orange chicken from take out and it has that one chili icon to indicate that it's spicy? that was about the same level as the dry chili chicken i received. the food wasn't horrible, but definitely not worth the long wait and mediocre service.

we arrive at the restaurant they sat us down pretty quick but after that it all went downhill they took 15 min just to take our order, to add to that one of the fork they gave us was dirty . the place is pretty crowded and super noisy you have to almost scream to have a conversation and you're super close to the table next to you not really a problem but just fyi. after 30 minutes of waiting for food to arrive it was just okay. although at the end the food actually made me get sick. i would totally recommend skipping this one.

this is probably one of my new favorite chinese restaurants. even before you walk in, there are many articles, pictures, and publications posted on the windows showing its notoriety. me and my fiancee headed down to chinatown to check out the annual summer fair and before we embarked to hit the fair we decided to grab some lunch. when we walked in it wasn't very full. there were a couple of empty tables and no line to be seated, but the wait staff was still hustling and bustling. we were seated promptly and given hot tea and a mildly spicy pickled cabbage for the table. the tea had a great tea flavor with a little sweetness and the cabbage was spicy and savory. we ordered the house special dry chili prawns and the mongolian beef tenderloin. both dishes were delicious! the prawns were coated with a crispy and crunchy batter and were covered in dry red chilies. although the chillies were piled on, the spice level was not through he roof. there was a good balance of savory and saltiness with a good kick of spice. it wasn't so spicy that you had to drink water after every bite . the mongolian beef is probably one of the best i ever had. good quality and fresh ingredients and you can tell it was cooked fresh to order. the vegetables were still a little crunchy and the sauce was amazing and coated everything and not just drenched. usual chinese food is pretty greasy and heavy but the preparation was light and didn't weigh you down.unless you couldn't stop eating cause it was so good. we highly recommend this place and i can't wait wait to go back just to try the other dishes. happy eating!

it was good! not mind blowing, but definitely tasty. i liked the seafood soup, the salt and pepper squid. we got a lot of fried stuff, and anything fried tastes good. the service was good and the cost reasonable. no complaints!
great services! great spicy food. we all love spicy fish with intestines, addition of pepper made the perfect taste!

i was in china a year or so ago. specifically in chengdu where sze chuan food is served primarily. i came here with my friend and had the twice cooked pork. he had the yu shiang pork (fish taste sauce pork). both were great dishes. i'd personally would have my friends dish over the twice cooked pork but that's my preference. staff was nice, atmosphere was calm and welcoming, and the overal portion sizes were adaquate for the amount being paid. i had left overs as well as my friend. it was quality food at a good price. though, this isn't a 1:1 for the food in china because they don't overdo the sze chuan pepper spice a good thing since most people here wouldn't be able to stand the high spiciness of the pepper, the food still tastes great. edit i realized what i ordered was a mild version of the dish. there is a spicier version which has more of the sze chuan pepper integrated within the dish.
truly good. we had lamb with cumin, sweet and sour ribs, wanton soup. all very good. very friendly owner meets you at the door. service was great. i think we will be back tomorrow.
the best one to visit in my opinion! everything is good, i love the cucumber salad and the mapo tofu!

this place is a huge disappointment. the food isn't bad but the service is extremely terrible and the plates aren't clean which is a huge turn down for us. when we came in and sat down at a table, nobody bothered to give us menu. we had to get the menu from the table next to us since there was a big pile there. i checked in on yelp to get the free egg roll and i asked the waitress but she barely understood english. i asked her if i could speak with a manager or someone who could speak english but she just went away without trying to find someone to help/speak with us. i had to try to wave at another waiter myself and the guy understood but never brought out the complimentary eggroll for us. i ended just not asking for it anymore. we ordered a few basic items like the pea pod stem, spicy sze chuan fish soup and soup dumplings. the fish soup is good but the soup dumplings are very mediocre. they're super small and there's not any soup in the dumplings. i was extremely disappointed since i expected this place to have at least average quality and service. would never come back again.

thought i would try this place today, but then checked out the reviews and pictures so glad i did since i saw the picture of the dead roach in someone's meal. definite turn off. i don't know if you can fix this type of problem but not willing to take the chance. this place is definitely off my bucket list and that of my friends. yuk!

a small, fast service, delicious food find in chinatown with unparalleled szechuan cooking and the largest menu in the midwest. probably. try the specials try old favorites, don't forget the sweet sour soup. reasonable price, but that means popular
good food horrible service. that is how i summarize this resturant. soup came in after entree. wrong order had to send it back

i waited a full week to see if my initial feelings would soften with this restaurant.it didn't, and this will be my first, and hopefully last, bad yelp review. everyone has a bad day but even if that were the case here, there is more than enough to critique unfavorably with lao sze chuan. my issues are mainly the service and the unauthentic sichuan cuisine. service: it changed from acceptable to non existent and unexplanably testy. when we ask why it was taking long between the first to last dish (25 minutes) the wait staff became rude and ignored us. customers coming in after we asked were served before our last three dishes arrived. they treated us like lepers. unacceptable! unprofessional! food: we ordered six entrees and all were average at best, a couple unacceptable. i will comment on three in particular: 1) spicy governor's chicken (menu item 561) not authentic sichuan! had no chinese vegetables, only baby corn from a can and green bell peppers. the chicken chunks were 75% batter. sauce was gummy and tasteless.just hot from the chili peppers. what a ripoff! 2) stew beef trim flank noodle soup (item 701) soup was spicy from all the hot oil spilled into the bowl. mostly noodles and very little flank meat. the only flavor/taste was hot from the oil, not complex, layered or sophisticated in the least. 3) chef's special dry chili chicken (item 5633) nothing special here unless one likes paying 13.95 for a plate of chili peppers (see pictures on yelp) and some batter fried chicken. this is not authentic sichuan. no flavor, just painfully hot from the copious amount of chilis. this is not a good sichuan chinese restaurant. the food plays off the spicy sichuan nature but its just hot, unsophisticated, unauthentic, american chinese entrees. if you're looking to test your man vs. food machismo, you might consider this (or just buy a bag of dried chilis instead). otherwise, find some other place to spend your hard earned money on enjoyable food.

finally had the opportunity to make it over to lao sze chuan.did my research long before i even set foot here.saw award after award.im in the chinatown area aloooot.sometimes everydaye.i work walking distance from here.first theywasn started me off with a complimentary spicy cabbage appetizee that was delicious.schezuan chinese food is mostly spicy but they do offer non spicy items as well as items here can be ordered not spicy.i love spicy food so eating here is right up my alley.service was ok.wasnt great but wasnt horribly bad.it wasnt a busy night.my normal chinese go to spot had a line out the door on memorial day which is how i ended up at lao sze chuan.the menu is craaaazy! must have about 100 different dishes.i ordered the lamb in cumin sauce.it was huuuuuge! definitely bang for the buck on the food from what i can tell.place is nice.be a good place to bring a date or a friend.i enjoyed my visit.i ordered an extra serving of the complimentary spicy cabbage and was charged 5.i get they have to make money but reeeaaally?! im not deducting a star for that though.at least i'll know for next time.im already spending money on food and beer.least you coulda thrown me an extra complimentary cabbage.just saying.kinda like mexican places give free chips.my dinner with 3 beers was 45.so yeah,i vote free cabbage.lol.next time i wanna be brave enough to try the spicy frog! sure,i'll go back next time my usual spot is jamm packed.food was great but my dinners at chinatown usually dont cost me fifty bucks!
dirty sticky floor. dirty sticky menu. dirty sticky chairs. waiters mostly ignoring us. avoid if possible
good lord. this was great. try the tony chicken and the double fried pork fat. yes. fat. it was yummy.

went to a chinatown restaurant renowned for not for the faint of heart spicy cuisine. the descriptions suggested non stop diarrhea and heartburn, so i high tailed it there. is bullshit one word? because that's the word to describe the claims. i ordered the two of the spiciest dishes there (chili chicken and fried noodle with pork and calamari) and it wasn't even tinley park people spicy. if you don't have to down a whole beer after a few bites to not scream in pain, you don't get to call yourself that spicy. and if you don't even need a glass of water? you're a damn joke. there was no fire to put out whatsoever. so any diarrhea i will experience tonight is the result of nerve damage due to diabetes. here was my fortune: the luck that is ordained for you will be coveted by others the restaurant was filled with rich white people. two kinds: old rich whites who moved back into the city when the nest went empty people who assume their luxury condos make them chicagoans who might boink trustfund kids (the peers of their own children) in bucktown. the other kind were those who still have brats and live in southern lake county. i was seated next to a group of those, nearest a woman with an infant in a stroller. when she saw me she looked at me like a turd that might ooze turd juice onto the little future entitled american she was raising. so she pulled the stroller closer to herself. i suppose it would be spicy for her. right when i made it to my car and lost my parking (no free parking anywhere near the place), i had to pee. the asian walgreens worker at the adjacent.walgreens lied and said the bathroom was out of order. so i went to ricobene's. i stopped to buy a strawberry shake and it was amazing, exactly what i wanted and didn't know i did. i was going to smoke my 2 cigar while i drank it, but it was too good to risk contaminating. now i'm listening to ass ponys in the parking lot and smoking the aforementioned cigar. in about five minutes, i'll put in the magnificent pat hughes and listen to him describe a baseball game that despite the crushing absurdity and disappointment of life i still care about. this is enough. plenty actually.

looking for a good chinese restaurant since our go to place has closed. tried lao sze chuan takeout. ordered shrimp fried rice, pork fried rice and curry chicken. the fried rice was burned and they gave it to us anyway! i had to return it the next day for a replacement order. apparently they didn't clean the pan very well because the rice still had a burnt scent. we'll keep looking! no recommended!

i excited to come here. but, it did not live up to my expectations. we ordered beef, pork, and it looked delicious. but when it arrived, the whole dish was very lacking in flavor and whole dish seemed like it wasn't seasoned at all which is the complete opposite of what i was expecting. it was definitely not worth it. the last, when we get bill to pay, the waitress added tips in bill and hidden tip leaved tip area empty, i would not return here and not recommendation

this is long time fav of my brother so we decided to try. we were looking for good chinese not really crazy the restaurants in old town area. wow delicious not greasy or fatty. we went very traditional beef n broccoli, orange chicken beef fried rice and crab rangoon and tried a order of spring rolls even though we were look for tradition egg rolls but they don't have these. the spring rolls were very good light n crispy good veggie flavor. then the fried rice is clean no film lard taste after eating. wish we would have went for shrimp fried rice after reading reviews. we're not big on spicy but the chicken chili looked delicious and found out after we ordered you can order it non spicy but we will know for next time. the orange chicken was battered and lightly dressed in sauce not drowned which made the 15 min ride home lovely food was still warm and not soggy. the beef n broccoli again wasn't drowned in sauce broccoli still had crisp and beef was good quality and tender not fatty. our fav thing hands down crab rangoon omg chunks of crab and nice consistency and not greasy at all nice crunchy so good. it was packed at 830pm on cold n raining evening on a saturday of mother's day weekend, our food only took 15 mins to prepare for our take out. and so much food for 51 dollars. would definitely recommend only down fall is no egg rolls.

the waitress is good, food is not too bad. however, the tricks this restaurant played gets me pissed off. taking me as a fool by adding tip themselves, wtf? i don't believe it is typo as machine won't lie, watch out before you signing the bill! i traveled most cities and no one chinese restaurant did like this, shame on you!

what's the deal?! this place has been around for awhile now and there's still not enough staff? it is always flooded with people. they don't listen to what you have to say when ordering. they just nod and agree and move on. now for the food. you must try the tony's chicken. i'm vegan but hadddd to try it. wow! it's just like popcorn chicken but better! we also tried the fried duck. no. just don't. it's super dry and you'll regret it. i tried the main tofu dish. it looks like a soup but over rice it's very good. be cautious! this dish is very spicy. i wasn't pleased with the staff or the very small establishment.

don't really like this place to be honest, the food is mediocre. the overall cleanliness was not so appealing. it seems like they don't keep their restaurant very well kept. and the staff however lacked manners. we got a waitress that demanded that we give her a tip but she came to our table only twice and thats it. she really was trying to make sure we gave her tip. but she really did nothing to earn it. the overall experience with this place i give it one star. why because there was nothing that could balance out the experience.

the old standby, but still reliably good. your meal starts off with spicy marinated cabbage salad. can't figure out how they make this, but it's excellent. (hint: if you go very late at night the cabbage is pretty spicy.) spicy szechuan standbys are the best bit here: the ma po tofu is second to none, full of leeks and tingly with szechuan peppercorns. the potstickers are delicious in an old school large and greasy kind of way. i like the steamed dumplings too, but somehow my companion always wants the potstickers. the spicy crispy items are great if you are prepared to eat deep fried stuff. they come on a plate laden with red peppers. these add flavor, but they don't make the dish too hot; don't eat them. there's nothing fancy about this place; there's white paper on the table and everything feels a little chaotic, in a friendly sort of way. it can get crowded; find the jovial host and make sure you get a number if you need to wait. there is now lots of good szechuan food in chicago, but we do seem to keep coming back here.

1) i placed an order and when it was delivered it looked nothing like the description. i even called and asked for a description of what i ordered (just to make sure i wasn't crazy) and what was in front of me looked nothing like what was described. she kept speaking over me and telling me i ordered wrong when they actually delivered wrong. hung up while i was speaking. extremely rude. 2) the liquid from the order was spilled over into the bag as if they just throw the things around without any type of care.
i really enjoyed their sweet and sour chicken, and i'm eager to try the more traditional szechuan dishes when i go back. also, they gave us a lot of great food for our film shoot.

i'm unsure why the ratings are so high when the food is so horrible! i paid 18 for my chow mein, delivery, and tax. i will pay for good food. this wasn't it. what i received was fried dry thin spaghetti noodles, over cooked chicken pieces, and overcooked shrimp. today was the first day i threw away an entire meal. my co workers did the same thing. 3 meals, 3 packets of soy sauce, a garbage can full of their food. save yourself the trip. find another restaurant.

first time to chicago and our coworker had to bring us here. it was good but i've definitely had better there were a few touches that really stood out and made the meal memorable. all meals start off with a pot of tea and some spiced cabbage. great to nibble on while looking at the {overwhelming} menu! we ordered the ham and chicken rice, chicken fried rice, kung pao, and general tso chicken. the battered pieces of chicken were just wayyy too battered. it was a 50/50 ratio chicken to breading. flavor was bland. fried rice was delicious and the only thing i took multiple helpings of.

not good. the food was nothing special and i think the restaurant is overrated. we ordered xiaolongbao and the meat smelled and tasted real bad. their signature menu seemed to be the chili chicken but it wasnt special either:( very disappointing

i had heard of this place many many years ago, however was not able to get a table until finally this weekend. it was very good chinese food, the staff were all polite and friendly, but what shocked me the most was how quick the food came out. most of the chinese restaurants i have gone to bring out a dish at a time, but here all the food came out piping hot maybe not even 10 minutes after we ordered. 11/10 would come again.
the service is a little slow here but the food is wonderful! they always start off by giving the table a plate of spicy cabbage, this stuff is amazing!

tip: if you pay in cash, you get 10% off the bill. i'm always a big fan of szechuan food, and this place is no exception. just a note, if you're not a fan of spicy food, this is probably not the restaurant for you. as compared to most szechuan restaurants, i'm used to, the portions are really big. they really don't skimp on the meat at all like some i've been to. my boyfriend and i come here pretty often. we usually order twice cooked pork and some sort of fish that i don't know the name of. those two dishes and rice alone are enough to fill us up and have plenty for leftovers. we once ordered the hot and sour soup, and that was good as well. never have to complain about the food because it's always solid. the staff is quite nice as well. big portions, reasonable prices, and great food. you really can't beat this place!

this place can get pretty packed, and we were seated pretty quickly. i don't see the point in getting a quick seat though, but taking forever to get a server. the food was great and very authentic, just like you would get in china. as a matter of fact i thought i was in china for a minute because the staff seemed to speak very little english and the decor was cute. i will be back.

my husband and i were not fans of chinese food until we tried this place! it's best to go with a group so you can try a bunch of different dishes. they have a ton of options for vegetarians! some of our favs are their mapo tofu (highly recommend this if you enjoy spicy food!), garlic sauce eggplant, and chow mein. ambiance and service aren't the best, but the food makes up for it.

visited for lunch on president's day and the food was great, but the service was underwhelming. it took about 2.5 hours to have lunch because the staff was not attentive to our table. i'd visit again, but definitely not for a quick bite.

amazing tbh i finally found a chinese restaurant that is good the food is very good quality i ordered the salt and pepper shrimp the dumplings are good very good fried rice large menu with many selections :) service is very friendly would recommend this to anyone

might be one of the worst chinese take out food i've ever had. took 1.5 hour for delivery on a normal weekday. so obviously it was cold when it got here. had no flavor, order chicken fried rice for old lady and took once bite and threw the rest away. i will never order from them again.
this has the best dry chili chicken in town. service isn't amazing anywhere in chinatown, but this place has great food and they chilli chicken is amazing.

glorified, white washed, chinese food. there were 13 of us therefore much food was ordered. a few dishes were heavy on the ginger. the others weren't any better than i could get anywhere else outside of china town. they were understaffed so service was just a step above terrible. the wait staff never wanted to make eye contact. we were constantly asking for simple things like. refills on our water. it was our family's christmas dinner. it was disappointing. sadly.

if you like spicy food, you will like this place. i'm talking about spicy spicy spicy food. this food is not made for the weak. i love szechuan food. i lived in nyc for 5 years and i was first introduced to szechuan food there and got hooked on it ever since. listen most of their food is made with peppers, chili, etc. it's spicy hot. if you don't like spicy food, don't go. it's as simple as that. if you like sweating, and i'm talking about dripping sweat and if you like your tongue being numb spicy, then this place is for you. just a warning it's not for the weak. i love their dry chili chicken. it's their specialty. can't go wrong with it. i'm also obsessed with their boiled beef in spicy szechuan sauce these days. this dish is going to make you hot spicy hot. it comes out in soup but when you mix it with rice and your tongue is numb from it, and your dripping sweat from your face, you know the dish is good. hahaha i might be crazy. i also get their twice cooked pork and mapo tofu. can't go wrong with that. this food is not for the weak. explore other areas of chinatown. explore meals outside of orange chicken. give it a shot. you might love it like i do, or hate it like my girlfriend does. lol. fyi this place is a lot better and cheaper than their michigan ave location.

a popular sichuan flavor restaurant in north america. the flavor has been adjusted to american taste. this restaurant is a little old and the one in downtown is recently furnished with a better environment.

this is probably the worst chinese restaurant that i've tried in a long time.and they stated they are the best(?) at least, i don't think it's a good chinese restaurant for chinese~most customers there were not chinese. we ordered a couple small dishes and 2 entrees that should be very basic and traditional for sichuan restaurant, unfortunately, we didn't like any of them. and the sour and spicy rice/crystal noodle(suan la fen) was not cooked through, we told the server, and she asked us to pour back the portion we put in our own bowls to the big bowl, and brought it back to re cook it. i was feeling uncomfortable at that point already, and when she brought it back, i don't really see any difference in the noodle,except it's hotter. she was nice enough to let us return that dish though. overall, we had a lot left over, even though we were pretty hungry.not worth the risk to try it out again based on service and food qualify we got this time.
what a horrible experience. dirty, inattentive service, terrible chairs and the food was almost inedible. we've eaten at their skokie location and loved it. so disappointing.would never go back.

the food here is really really really salty. the spiciness level is pretty good but they rely on salt far too much it's basically all of the flavor involved in each dish. it is also more relatively more expensive compared to the other places in chinatown without being better

i'm from new york. this is the first time i've come to this place. there is no direct service also added my 18% tip, and no said to us, i was almost fooled by them, i won't come to this place, please don't go to, the chinese discrimination against chinese! i wish i hadn't been to this restaurant!
bleh. not sure how this place became known as king of chinatown. thought it was terrible. hair in our food, super salty and overpriced. thumbs down. tea was also cold. pass.

my visits to chinatown are pretty standard. candy store, dim sum, bubble drinks and maybe a knick knack store. so when my friend and i decided to try hot pot, it was a little out of my comfort zone. and when there is a divide in the language department, it's even more out of my comfort zone. but we did it, and came away full and with more knowledge on what to do next time. the menu is huge. they have americanized chinese food and more authentic dishes. and looking around at other diner's plates, we figured they weren't kidding when it shows spicy on the menu. lots of chili peppers in here! we opted for the two broth hot pot spicy and non spicy. and we went with the deluxe options, which from what i understood, was supposed to include all the meat and veggies. but i didn't see all the seafood on the menu come through to our plates, not sure why. but anyway, the duo pot comes with the broths and portable stove/heater. then you start adding the meats and veggies to the broth and start eating when it's cooked. you are also given 3 sauces garlic, soy and peanut to add to your own dish to add more flavor and depth. then once you have added lots of meats/veggies, the cooking broth gets more flavorful and flavorful so if you've added noodles, you are left with a wonderful soup too! my friend and i found the spicy side way too salty. they even changed the broth for us but we still found it too salty for our taste. they brought out a new non spicy broth for us, gratis. wow. that's service! the kid's shrimp fried rice and fried shrimp were also very good and they enjoyed it as well. fun visit.
ok. service food good dumplings no flavor wonton soup free hot tea not greasy tommy is cute with his huge gold chain necklace the temperature is freezing in there. no heater
solid restaurant right in the heart of downtown chinatown. spicy means spicy here, so just keep that in mind. really enjoyed everything we had, especially spicy dry chili chicken and hot beef.

a group of us went for all you can eat hotpot (you only get a few shrimp for the whole table. if you want more shrimp, it is 6 more for 7 shrimp). well, how is that all you can eat. plus, at 20.99 a person, there are cheaper alternatives in chinatown. as usual, the food is pretty good and the service is average. looking for a new hotpot place .
great szechuan place in chicago. i only had the take out, but it was good. might be a little less authentic, but not bad. not too spicy and decent portion size.
outdated interior. dirty plates. disappointingly low quality of the food. waitress refused to take back undercooked rabbit stew. never again, lao sze chuan.

honest review: i liked the food but the restaurant is extremely dirty not like jus one section everywhere the front was dirty n the bathrooms were dirty so based on that the kitchen must he dirty i usually only rate reviews based solely on the food unless the cleanliness is bad since it was dirty i would not come back however if u like eating in a pigsty then more power to uthen the service was meh not very helpful at all best things: dan dan noodles/ mapo tofu spring roll: this was free but i didnt really like it wasnt that flavorful and wasnt hot it was like barely lukewarm dan dan noodles 6.45 this was really tasty its basically deep fried meat and a sauce at the bottom and you mix it up together. its really tasty the only issue is i wish there was more sauce and meat because theres not enough mapo tofu with pork 14.95: i loved this it was so spicy and rich i loved the beans in here that added a great salty flavor i wish there was more pork seafood hotpot 20.95: i was mislead i thought this was like your typical hotpot its more like a lemon grass soup its really tasty wish there was more veggies and seafood n hold back on the lemon grass overwhelmed the other ingredients smoked tea dick 15.95 this was amaizin duck was really crispy however there wasnt alot of meat more bone then meat n it needed seasoning loved the sauce it was sweet and went perfectly with the duck

i'm no connoisseur of chinese cuisine, but based on other recent reviews, this place was better than anticipated. food was delicious and fairly priced, and the service was perfectly fine. maybe it's because we were a group of 4 on a tuesday evening, but the service wasn't nearly as bad as i was anticipating from other reviews. the staff was attentive, very friendly, and mostly fast. they brought one of the many dishes out late, but eh, that happens. highly recommend!
my favorite restaurant in chinatown. you should definitely try the all you can eat chinese hotpot.

this used to be my favorite chinese restaurant. looks it has won many awards as well. the food is good but the service has gone down. in today's visit i had the worst experience at this place. yes, it was busy and the staff was not friendly at all. it took them 20 mins to take the order. they forgot one of the items i had ordered. the staff kept ignoring everytime i tried to get their attention. i was very unhappy with the service and when i saw the check it completely blew my mind. they already included the tip in the check for a table for three. i'm sorry this one is new to me. i have never seen this before where they include the tip even for a table for three in the check. in my opinion, if you want to get treated really bad and still have to pay for the service please go to the this place.

excellent food. we ordered crispy shrimp in lemon sauce, pork in garlic sauce, mongolian beef, shrimp in lobster sauce, and rib tips with a salt and pepper seasoning. all were top notch. i did not give them a fifth star only due to the very basic ambiance. the meal was not expensive but was not cheap either. i would love a better ambiance for such a good a meal.
we thought hot and sour soup and the shrimp fried rice were excellent. the speedy service was outstanding too! the hot tea and hot cabbage appetizer were included.

it breaks my heart to give only a 2 star review to an establishment that was my favorite spot in this chinatown ~10 years ago. being from around the region, i frequently visit chinatown and over the years have dined at lsc numerous times. the trend is clear, lsc is just relying on its former glory. service is not much different than the other restaurants in the area so let's focus on food. on my last visit, my family and i ordered three dishes (wife and husband platter, twice cooked pork, and spicy pork stew). the wife and husband platter was bland. clearly from a pre made batch that's been sitting there for at least a day. there was no presence of the expected numbing flavors associated with this traditional dish. the twice cooked pork was filled with slices of pure pork fat and drowned in an over salted black bean sauce. the spicy bok choy stew was served with some pork . overall, these dishes are missing the savory spice that made lsc popular years ago. will probably visit in 6 months and hope they can turn this decline around.

if you wanna go there. girls have to be careful!i saw one of the managers (the old guy) touch a girl by force in today. that girl was so scared, and run away. just protecting you girl when you are eating in this restaurant. good luck guys!

while in chicago, my uber driver recommended this restaurant in chinatown, which was right across the street from the hotel where i was staying. ma pao tofu and dry chili chicken were noted as star dishes, so ordered both. while they both were different than other chinese or szechuan dishes i had ever had, the tofu was so spicy (should have expected as much) that i could only eat a few bites. service was not impressive and they charge extra for rice, which seemed a little absurd given the 20+ price tag for each dish, a little higher than your typical asian spot. that being said, it was fun to experience something so authentic in chinatown. probably wouldn't come back or recommend this place to others, but it was still a neat experience.
