this place does not know spicy, only knows how to douse every dish in oil from their chili sauce.jus not my thing.
the salt and pepper fish was amazing. great breading and seasoning, done with finesse (not at all greasy). really enjoyed the dinner there. it's a big menu, so we'll be back!

first things first. if you're expecting perfect service from a chinatown restaurant, despite it's renowned name, then you're setting yourself up for disappointment. as a frequent chinatown restaurant frequenter (philly, nyc, boston, dc, chicago) i'll say the service is about on par with other chinatown restaurants. they're simply not trained like they would normally be. thus, this review is based solely on the food. this is my second time to lao sze chuan as it is my second time to chicago. on my first trip, we ordered a plethora of szechuan dishes which is what they're known for. the food is as good and as authentic as it gets in the states. we ordered four szechuan items and all were fantastic. we got ma po tofu, dry chili chicken, hot and sour soup and i don't remember the last dish. all were 5/5 but be warned that they don't wimp out on their spices. it's legit szechuan food. on the second trip, we ordered non szechuan dishes since our party did not want spicy food. it's quite a step down, but this is like ordering a chicken sandwich from a well known burger restaurant. it's just not going to be the same. the food is still quite good and better than most places but if you go here, definitely go szechuan.

i ordered through grub hub and oh my god the crab rangoon is soooooo good and the shrimp fried rice is amazing ! for real best chinese delivery i've had in years. it was freaking amazing. everyone needs to try this place it's delicious. i should have ordered more crab rangoon hahahahha

went with this spicy chicken dish recommended by tony bourdain. dry chili chicken. hot, yes. tasty, check. would i rush back or even go back with friends? not likely. while it made the grade for a decent dinner. i can say it was rather bland. and full of hot flavorless heat. i did find the hot and sour soup to be rich and flavorful. the veggies and tofu inside cooked perfectly. the rice served with the dish was a great mode of delivery for the chicken and masked some heat. a highlight i can leave with is the environment feels smells and sounds like the heart of asia! it's worth a trip. just not too often in this neck of the woods for chicago. fyi they have other locations in the city. near river north and further up south of evanston.
food is ok. but some dishes you can tell are not fresh (e.g. the steamed ribs might be leftovers from the day before). took a cab to visit lao sze chuan when visiting chicago. very disappointed.

my husband and i dined in this restaurant around 3:15 pm on 08/29/17. the service was ok. the dishes we ordered, as follows, were all awful and not authentic at all. 1) sole fish fillet chili bean sauce (dou ban yu pian ) 15.95 the little sorry fish fillets were heavily wrapped in thick batters cooked in a corns starched red sauce. it tastes all salty but nothing else. 2) szechuan string beans (gan bian si ji dou ) 11.95 this is definitely not the szechuan string beans that was supposed to be lots of un dissolved salt all over the beans. again, only salt but no flavour at all. 3) ma po tofu (ma po dou fu ) 11.95 very salty. again, it only tastes salts but nothing else. totally caused us 46.66 (including 2.00 white rice and taxes) before tips. we only ate 5% of the food and left behind, and continued to look for a next reasonable place for our lunch. absolutely a ripoff. certainly we're not going to come back to this restaurant ever.

horrible service. after waiting for a while we asked how much longer would be, and the guy taking names (who acted as if he was the owner) started yelling at us saying he has so many customers, he doesn't care if we eat there or not. the food is excellent, but our experience was like the soup nazi from seinfeld.

bummed about my recent experience. moreso because of the service. ive been multiple times here pros portions great for sharing prices are fair for portions quick service my favorite is the orange chicken which was delicious as always. its crispy! i highly recommend the restaurant wasn't even busy , we did an early bird dinner . they forgot our appetizers, we reminded them and got them at the end and i felt like they were trying to rush us out, even as we were still eating and ordering drinks . i felt very unwelcome with my group this experience makes me think i will try a new chinatown restaurant next time

this review is for the service only. came here for dinner, and waited for more than 20 minutes, but nobody took our order. the table next to us paid the bill but had to wait more than 15 minutes just to get a box for leftovers. when we mentioned to tommy, (the owner?) we were ready, he rudely dismissed us. we waited for a few more minutes, but left when still no one showed up to take our order. as we left, we saw tommy chase down two customers and ask them to pay for his tip. we were glad we left, but we were sorry for the almost half an hour lost.

the food here is really good (5 stars), but the customer service is truly bad, making it a two star experience. the dishes were dirty. tea cups were not clean on the inside. we asked for a clean cup, got another one with some dirt on the bottom. looked like someone just wiped the first cup with dry napkin, and whatever dirt rolled and fell on the bottom, that's what we got. .asked for an extra empty bowl, this lady gives us the bowl while her two fingers are on the bowl. hmmm, hello department of health, could you please swing by? asked for another water glass, got excellent glass, but with food residue. hello? the hostess, the guy with deep voice and tons of jewelry, didn't even say good bye to us. it goes without saying, people hardly understand/speak english. overall, feels like a restaurant from some third world country that has no comprehension about public safety.

lao sze chuan is one of my favorite restaurants in chicago. this chinatown location is less upscale and clean than their location on michigan ave, but it's cheaper and also very good for groups. definitely order their dry chili chicken. you will thank me later! it is literally one of my favorite dishes of all time. some other go to's are the mapo tofu, boiled beef in spicy szechuan sauce, twice cooked pork, and sliced beef and maw szechuan style. pretty much anything you order will be yummy. they also usually give you some free spicy cabbage to start, which is spicy but delicious. the service overall is fine, but don't expect top of the notch. you definitely come here for the food, not for the service or overall experience. this place is still highly recommended though! i will be coming here for many years to come.
if you are looking for spicy chinese food, this is definitely the place to go. a little pricy though.

this is one of the most authentic sichuan restaurants in the us. it is spicy, oily, big portions, flavorful. i had the spicy beef soup, dan dan noodles, and sichuan chicken all of which left me as a hot mess drinking down my tsing dao's. the menu is comprehensive which will make choosing difficult. it is easy to find and popular. if you are in chinatown in chicago and want the heat this is the place to go!

most of the food was incredibly spicy. not yummy, accent the food spicy, but fire shooting outta your mouth spicy. my lips honestly were tingling for hours afterwards. two out of the four at our table could barely eat. we were blasting through water and it was never refilled without us asking. besides the overwhelming spice, the food was run of the mill. we got fried rice for a friend to go and that was very good. but overall, the food and service weren't anything special.
authentic spicy sichuan food, good as always. boiled beef is a must every time i go.

come hungry or bring a friend! the portions are family style and meant to be shared. my group tried ordering individually, and we had plenty of leftovers. the food is great too. i ordered the dry chili chicken and the boiled chili beef. both were great, but the boiled beef was the clear winner. the beef sits in a sichuan chili broth that brings just the right amount of heat and a nice range of flavor. the beef was cooked well and the vegetables complimented the broth and beef well. it can get kinda spicy so be prepared for that. the chicken was fried well, not too much breading, not too much crunch. even fried and in smaller portions the chicken kept it's natural flavor. this too is served with chili peppers which made the dish that much better. if you are a fan of spicy or savory food that comes in big portions come find this place tucked away in the western corner of chinatown square. my only complaint is that the service for water was slow at the start. they eventually brought our table a pitcher though. would go again.this week.
does not live up to the hype. super greasy and the noodles were overdone very soggy, very salty.

i finally made it to lao sze chaun and it didn't disappoint. the food can be quite spicy (szechuan style after all), which i like, but be wary if your spice tolerance is low. the dry chili chicken, spicy pork, and beef noodles are all fantastic. i can't wait to go back and try more of the menu.

service is awful when i tried to order delivery. they picked up the phone and was talking for 30 seconds to someone else without even talking to me. right after i told them my payment information, i was trying to ask them how long it will take, they hung up on me.

this place is amazing if you want traditional szechuan food. it's not your regular take out chinese food it's going to be spicy and flavorful. you may be sweating while eating it, but you won't regret it. the most amazing thing to me is the number of options they have not only for meat eaters but also vegetarians. the mapo tofu is a must. the tofu tastes like butter so silky and smooth and the chili oil that it's cooked in is to die for. i can't generally handle too too much spice but this was so flavorful that i didn't mind that my mouth was on fire later. food is family style so order to share. others in our group got the cumin lamb and dry chili chicken and said it was amazing. there's also a really helpful chef's recommendations in the beginning of the menu, and i think all of our dishes were on that. the hot and sour soup is also good, but not the most amazing one i've ever had. you have to ask them for the white rice and they do it by portion size. the service is not awesome but the food makes up for it. just keep making eye contact with the waiter / waitress in order to place your order / get that second glass of water / or some napkins.

what a sorry ass place! the owner? manager? actually yelled at me right after i walked in. he confused me with someone else, i guess. don't know, don't care. after i was seated i detected a nasty smell. couldn't pinpoint the location. it smelt like dirty mop water and piss. lost my appetite, left. (folks, take note of the photo someone posted on here awhile back with the dead cockroach on the edge of the plate! discovered that photo after i left. dodged a bullet here today for sure!)

the food is ok here the service on the other hand bad. if you come with small kids be aware that a lot of food here is spicy. i tried the food very original but i think i like hong ming in palos hills for my taste. i usually love all kinds of food but i don't like fish food if it tastes fishy and one of our dishes had that fishy taste the restaurant also is not very clean. if i see dirty carpets or dirty floors and horrible bathrooms it means that the food is not going to be the cleanest or fresh prepared. i will not return back when i see this little defects. i did enjoyed some parts of the foods and not the service.

what a menu! it was huge and had many, many items that i hadn't seen before. there were many chinese people eating here, which is a good sign as far as i'm concerned. our group ordered a lot of different things, and everything was good. it was spicy and delicious. would go back for sure.

the quality or the food does not match the reputation of the restaurant. the quantity of the dishes is incredibly small. especially for the bullfrog gan guo niu wa ,there is at most one bullfrog in the 25 dollar dish. it was unbelievable. drinks are quiet expensive. you cannot say anything good about the servers either. they are impatient.

we came here based on a recommendation and i could not be more disappointed. first they made us wait more than 20 minutes just to take our order and then another 20 minutes to get our food. when the food arrived it came out in pieces, which cause some in our group to wait an additional 15 minutes before they got their food. if the food was not spicy, it was bland. the servers were also kind of rude to us. do not recommend.
omg, super delicious! the only place i will order chinese food from! be careful because it is really spicy, but enjoy! we always get the mao tofu, mongolian beef, and egg drop soup.

first, take care this restaurant that it charged you tips already in your total and if you write down the tips on payment, you will pay that for twice. this is fraud! secondly, as i am a chinese and came to si chuan more than five times, the food in this restaurant i will only give 2 out of 5 and around this restaurant there are so many good one, i came this restaurant just because i want to try a new one and i am so disappointed. overall, didn't recommend this restaurant.

this is wonderfully delicious sichuan cuisine we had an amazing meal here just today. ordered the mapo tofu and the chongqing la zi ji (spicy chicken chunks with dried chillis). the food was spicy, flavorful and best of all, as authentic as it comes. my only gripe about this place is the fact that it's so far away from where i live can the owners consider opening an outpost in the suburbs please?
crispy shrimp in mayonnaise sauce. get this. a perfect coordination between sweet, salty, and crispy. would come back soon just to get this again.

i came here because i saw good reviews but the definitely were misleading. the food here was sub standard, i have had a lot better elsewhere, and it did not help that the service was terrible! all the workers sat in the back and didn't seem interested in helping us at all. we had to ask multiple times for more water and all the workers just looked at each other as if they were playing tag to see who would be next to do some work.

if i could i wouldnt give this place any stars. first of all, the service was terrible! we were seated in the back corner where all the workers hung out. the food was very mediocre, every dish was drowned in soysauce! please do not eat here! i'm sure your better off eating at a panda express.

review for mapo tofu only i got the mapo tofu here and it was sppiiiicy even with the mild flavor. definitely authentic with a healthy dose of peppercorns. it was lacking that umami flavor and mostly packed heat. great to eat with rice as leftovers though. huge portions. i would get the boiled fish next time.

we won't go this place again. today, we went there for lunch with my wife and in laws. we intended to have lunch at minghin, but there was a 45min waiting time. we didn't want to wait, so we ended up to have lunch at lao szechuan, which is next door to minghin. we had to admit that it was a bad decision. we ordered kungpao chicken, doubly cooked pork and a few other dishes. the food was terribly salty. the kungpao chicken was salty, soggy with excessive sauce and chicken meat was unevenly chopped in irregular size. the taste does not live up to the szechuan cuisine standard. the worst part was the service. the waitress who served us didn't offer a friendly face. the way she spoke and the tone of her voice was cold. we regret that was bad experience at the so called flagship restaurant in chinatown.

i had high hopes for authentic sichuan food in a city as famous for its food as chicago is. this place was not terrible, but not great either. located in chinatown which is about 10 min drive from downtown chicago, it is a small strip of chinese restaurants and shops. lao sze chuan was relatively easy to find since it's on the edge of the strip, and there seems to be plenty of parking. the restaurant had a brisk business even on a monday night at 8pm, there were constantly people coming or going. the service was somewhat lacking, but par for the course for a chinese restaurant. the main issue was the quality of the food itself. the sichuan wontons were overly salty, and the dough didn't taste fresh. the twice cooked pork was fried well, but also overly salty (see a trend here). i thought the mapo tofu was decent, my friend thought it was overly salty. however, the fish in spicy oil was great, and the eggplant with ground pork was also very delicious (and none of them were overly salty as well). the prices were ok, not cheap, but not overly expensive as well. this is my first chinese restaurant in chicago, so i can't say if there's better or not, but i will be disappointed if this is the best.

i finally came to lao sze chuan after reading numerous good reviews. but. the food here is quite disappointing. we ordered dry chili chicken, blood pudding, beef trips in chili broth, both are typical sichuan specialties. the chili broth is very spicy but lack of flavor, chicken is too dry and i suspect the chicken isn't fresh enough. will never come back to this restaurant again.

i rarely write reviews.but this particular lao is absolutely wonderful. the staff is friendly and nice and always take care of me. i come at least 3 times a month if not more, and i plan to continue! thanks so much to all the staff here!
the food is unbelievable. the customer service is terrible. little to no english. the delivery times take about 1 2hours if that.

best chinese in the city, and my favorite place to get spicy food. highly recommend the house cabbage, twice cooked pork, extremely spicy beef/lamb/sole fish fillet, ma po tofu and honestly everything else on the menu. free chef tony

we actually were on our way to another restaurant, but decided to eat here instead. lucky me! food was so good, i had the postickers and salt and pepper seafood. i have gone to chinatown in chicago a few times and was never really impressed or happy with the food i was served. i will definitely be coming back again and again, there is a lot to try in their 50? 25? page menu binder.

this is my absolute favorite chinese restaurant. my husband and i drive an hour to eat here. the dry chili chicken and orange beef are our favorite things to order. we have had other things but we still go back to these two dishes. the food can be a little pricey but it's good quality food that is worth it. the staff is really sweet and on top of things. i would recommend trying this place if you have never been. it is totally worth it!

i was so impressed with this place. as a vegetarian, i was nervous about getting fish sauce / beef stock / pieces of chicken in my vegetarian food. (i've unfortunately had that experience at other restaurants in chinatown.) i explained right away that i don't eat any of that stuff, and our waiter was helpful in telling us what was truly veggie and what wasn't. i loved the mapo tofu (i don't normally go for hot stuff, but this was delicious and the chili flavor accentuated the food instead of burying it), the bean curd home style and the veggie fried rice. the meat eaters got meat stuff they enjoyed. the service was attentive, they constantly refilled our water, and the manager checked in at the end to make sure we enjoyed everything. i'm so happy to have a go to place in chinatown! look forward to coming back.

whenever i come to chicago, i ask my brother to go down to china town with me so we can eat here. i absolutely love it! do yourself a favor and order the tea duck! it's the one thing we always get. it's so rich and flavorful! i'm also a huge fan of their orange chicken, pork dumplings, pepper beef, and sweet and sour chicken. the pork fried rice is also quite nice! honestly, i haven't had anything here that i haven't enjoyed. order to share it's the only way to do it. we tend to get an entree per person and always end up with some wonderful leftovers. i'm sure there are a lot of great options in chinatown, but this place has my heart (and stomach)!
i order the flanky soup at least twice a week because it's fast and delicious. tonight. i've been waiting over 90 minutes. for one bowl of soup. ouch

this restaurant has become one of our regular spots for chinese food. we usually come on the weekends for dinner with a group of 8+ so it's great that they take reservations. some of my favorite dishes are the string beans, crispy shrimp with mayo sauce, and the chef's special dry chili chicken. we've never had any issues with the service here, they've always been really accommodating to our large group. definitely worth a stop if you're around chinatown.
we sampled many chinese restaurants in chinatown and this is the very best in our experience. spicy cabbage appetizer could be a meal in itself. it's in our regular rotation.

we came to this restaurant with high expectations based on their claim world's best chinese restaurant . sadly this was not the case. we were seated 12 minutes before anyone took our drink orders. the crab rangoon was very good, spring rolls just average. we ordered 3 entrees. however i never received my order! when i complained, the waitress said the kitchen is very busy, then proceeded to put my order in. since my family had already eaten, i had a terrible experience of watching them eat, while they were forced to wait for me! no apologies or an offer of comping anything!? terrible customer service. also, no diaper deck! so if you have young kids, (which most families who are visiting chinatown do), you are out of luck. good luck complaining also, the lady who was moving everyone along cleared our table, while we were still seated!?! wth? never again! an easy solution? learn english! my husband has english as his 2nd language, hire waitresses who can communicate with the patrons!

this was my first time in china town! my boyfriend wanted to try szechuan and found this spot after some quick research. i was shocked to see how many reviews this place had at first glance! it really is a no frills place, but the food and service were great. we ordered the pork dumplings, spicy dry chili chicken and twice cooked pork dishes. it was all veryyyyy good. we thought the dumplings would come out first, but they ended up coming last. they were fresh and tasty, and looked hand made. the pork dish was really good and we agreed they shouldn't call it fat on the menu, as it simply is pork belly (the title turns you off). the chicken is super crispy and tasty. i'm used to chinese food being saucy, so i was a little taken back at first. i was extremely full and satisfied after the meal, and only wish my water would've been refilled faster (that food is spicyyyyyy). the cabbage starter is delish and i wish i would've used my yelp check in deal. next time. also have to mention the interesting man sitting by the door (i think he's an owner. people were taking pics with him). he had quite the outfit complete with an enormous gold chain and championship looking rings on each finger. quit the experience!
perfect late lunch spot for me on mondays. peking dumplings are good and crispy duck is perfect. service is friendly.

the food was good, but the service is not that good.once my food was served waitress was in hurry to get us out of restaurant definitely not good place to spent time.when one goes for dine in they prefer to spent time. this is definitely not good choice for those.

ordered the spicy dry chili chicken and the pork dumplings. the spicy dry chili chicken was just okay, i was expecting more flavor and a wow when i bit into it. however it was more of a numbing dry chili taste. the chicken was super spicy and the chili taste left my tongue and mouth numb! so if you like the numbing flavors i would recommend. sadly the pork dumplings (xiao long bao) tasted like it was defrosted from a frozen package and steamed in a steamer. the juice from the dumpling wasn't as juicy and fresh as other ones i've tasted before.

have been here a few times and the food is phenomenal. if you want some real authentic chinese food, then do yourself a favor and try this place out. the variety and generous portions are enough to choose from without putting too much strain on your wallet. the seafood platter(shrimp, scallops and fish) is outstanding. service is a bit off but nothing that is a real serious issue. also, not too far from downtown chicago and other popular areas.

this place was ok. the food was a little less than mediocre. the service was attentive but there is a clear language barrier. the table next to us walked out since they couldn't get their order right. they were ordering crispy duck but the staff brought them smoked duck. it was a little difficult ordering our food as well. again, they were very attentive and my water was always refilled right away. this might have been a great place before ( a lot of old articles and awards posted) but i don't see it today or at least during our time here. i wouldn't recommend this place to anymore nor will i be coming back here.

came here a couple times before and i loved it both times. but when i went recently for my birthday dinner , it was completely terrible. we were sent upstairs, to the extra dining area. once we got seated, my parents, the two friends i brought and i all looked at each other uncomfortably. why? because the table was dirty! the middle glass piece had old drippings of different sauces i didn't even want to touch it! no one took out order for about 10 15 minutes. and after they did the food took even longer. plates were coming out individually instead of all together. one of the beef dishes that we ordered didn't even come out until we were almost finished with out meal. also, one of my friends, who ordered the beef noodle soup said it tasted like plastic due to how much grease it had! never again will i be coming here! there are better restaurants!

how can you charge 1 per person for steam rice? greedy. will never eat here again because you want me to pay extra for something that should be included with the overpriced entree. also the customer service here is a joke.
delivery came cold and chili chicken dish tasted like bad mall food and was 17 dollars. just a horrendous experience.

my wife and i recently visited chicago this past weekend with the intent of trying out a few new restaurants. having enjoyed our last trip to chinatown a few years back, we decided to try another restaurant in that area. we were very pleased with our experience, the food and the service. the hosts name is tommy, he's literally sitting at the very first table greeting everyone who walks through the door and walks then to their tables. the wait staff was so eager to serve us that they were fighting at the table over who was going to take our orders. taking each other's pens so the other couldn't write, it was quite comical. needless to say we had multiple people helping us through the entire meal. we ordered crab rangoons, chicken fried rice and fried pan noodles (pretty sure that was the name). everything was quite tasty with the exception of the chicken fried rice. just didn't quite taste what you think it should've tasted like. my wife ended up pretty much splitting my fried pan noodles with me. although the 1 food dish wasn't perfect, i cannot say we didn't have a 5 star experience. it's definitely worth a visit.
delicious food, with no frills atmosphere and service. very chinatown :)

one thing i miss in tampa is a restaurant that serves good spicy, szechuan cuisine. so when i was back in chicago for work i had to stop here for my szechuan fix. got my usual double cooked pork, which is thick cut, chinese bacon cooked in delicious spices.

my parents and i frequent lao sze chuan whenever we need a ma la spice fix. while they go heavy on the chili oil and other seasonings, i have never walked away regretting my decision to dine here, even the day before i ran the chicago marathon. in terms of appetizers, anything with a spicy dry rub or a chili oil concoction can do no wrong in my book. i especially enjoy the hot and spicy dry beef, the tripe, and the bamboo shoots. try not to fill up too much on these small plates, as the cold appetizers should only whet your appetite for the delicious entrees to come. i particularly enjoy their steamed fish which sounds boring and bland but is usually full of green onion, ginger, and lemon zest notes. for the antithesis of this dish, try the beef noodle soup (spicy, of course) with pickles. of course, for the vegetarians, i definitely recommend trying the garlic fried spinach as well as the crowd favorite, mapo tofu. these pillars of sze chuan cooking can do no wrong. the entire menu is extensive and wonderful, though i would ask your waiter for the freshest fish in the season. for the frequent yelpers out there, this restaurant does honor check in coupons, albeit they checked mine with the boss before pulling out the requested egg rolls. service has always been prompt and friendly though, full disclosure, we are a mandarin speaking household that orders completely in chinese. seating is family style on long tables with smaller party seating along the sides. there is also a large seating area upstairs (if you ever look into the restaurant and it looks packed, do not fear). overall, i've always had pleasant experiences here. my only regret is ingesting far too much spice for my own good because of the quality of the cooking here. oh, and did i mention the bottomless tea? definitely order the tea to wash down all those hot and spicy bites.

service is decent but chyu come fur da food. dey give free spicy pickled cabbage after u order and iz gud. we also got the free spring rolls dey offer on yelp, not very gud bruh frfr. dey sweet n sour sauce really be tastin like mcdonalds sweet n sour, i wuz impressed. if da food go in spicy, it gon come out da same. boiled beef gon make yo insides boil if you mix up dem chili flakes. if u like yo greens, get the garlic peapod leaves pricey and portion leaves wallet hurtin but iz gud with obvious slices of garlic. ain't no mosquito no vampire takin a bite outta chyus. mapo tofu on point and i like dey dry chili chickens. dis place as close to authentic chinese sichuan food as it gets in chitown. holla atchyo gurl.
um, this place knows nothing about spicy. it's just pure oil.pretty bad. will never come back.

i went here last friday to meet up some friends. my chinese friend loves this place. you step in and you're seated right away, granted we were there at 8:30 pm. i ordered kung pao pork liver. i have never had something like that before but i have an open mind. it was delicious. i shared with my friends and they loved it too. i suggest people go here for some authentic options. there are so many dishes; i am sure you will find something new.

we went to newly opened branch in evanston. my wife had a groupon just for this location. manager did not want to honor it, claiming that it is saturday and that the groupon is only valid on weekdays. she read it herself looking for exclusion and there was none. it is sad that the owner whose i new when he started very small at china square hired such a manager who would stoop to deceiving business practices. sorry, like your food but hate your service will not be going back.
i lived in chengdu, sichuan for years. pretty much the closest thing your going to get to sichuan food in chicago.
was going to try this place but seeing the staff on a cell phone is inexcusable. and a picture of a mouse in the restroom? the staff is lazy and careless. no thanks.

this is the worst experience i have ever had in chinatown. i usually go to chinatown for the food not for the service, but for the first time ever i walked out of a restaurant without eating anything. the wait staff essentially ignored us for for the better part of 30 minutes while i tried to catch their eye to order some food. i absolutely lost it when people who just got seated started getting their order taken, and yet again none of the servers would even look our way despite me trying to flag them down. really disappointed :(

i really don't know what's the big hype about. maybe customers are reviewing others than archer locations? you would think that chinatown should be a flagship location for this 3 sites restaurant. the food was bland and every sauce was thicken up with heaps of starch slurry . rice was extra, which i wouldn't mind if it was tasty. scallops were rubbery and not tasting very fresh. i ate only 2. overall cleanness and appearance not very inviting. i went on recommendation of my friend and yelp reviews and both of them were so wrong! that hardly ever happens to me. simply disappointing .

i came here for my love of chinese food and that this place is raved by vegetarians on yelp. i am giving it 2 3 stars for the ambience. sadly for me, ambience was about it. the food: i got their famous ma po tofu and an appetizer. the tofu came first and was so oily and piping hot that i couldn't eat it. too oily. when i did eat it, it was too spicy too although i ordered mild to medium spicy. i have tried a lot of chinese restaurants (east coast, nyc included), i know good chinese food and sadly this wasn't it. service: poor. the appetizer came after the food, i rejected to take it. the complimentary tea never came until i noticed and asked for it. they sat me right next to the door and it was cold outside. i was cold the entire time. cost: overpriced. 11.95 entree does not include rice. overall not that good of an experience. no one came to check as to how i was finding the meal either. i came here with a lot of hope, i hate giving bad reviews. also the guy in front tells everyone that there is a 25 min wait. when you accept it, they seat you right away.

sooooo i'm freaking out right now! let me start off by saying i've dined here before about 4 years ago and loved the food. my husband i were in the neighborhood today (date night away from kids) :) and decided let's go back! oh my god was is the worst mistake! we sat at our table greeted by a nice gentleman then some short lady popped out of nowhere and said order?.uhhh i'm thinking.yes, yes i want to order! we order our food, i had what i ordered years ago the mongolian beef and the spicy fried rice. my husband got the spicy double fried chicken. while we were waiting for our food to come out, i decided to use the restroom.ok this is where the nightmare begins! i enter the stall and when i look down i saw a round brown object, now i didn't have my glasses on (i'm blind with o) i go in my purse and put on my glasses and its a mouse! i immediately try to stay calm open the door and call for anyone to come look, there is a mouse in the bathroom! our waitress looks and has a shocked looked and says ok.ummmm ok what lady? jesus! there is a fucking mouse, excuse the language but really that's all you say ok another lady comes from the kitchen, saw the mouse and says omg, i'm so sorry i took pictures, lots of pictures.when i came out of the restroom the food was at the table. i'm super angry, my husband asks what's wrong, i tell him, he says let's go i say it's our date night we only get one every so many months.we have a show to get to at 6pm we don't have time to eat anywhere else.we stayed, i know.why? but i was hungry and well.i was hungry ok, don't judge! meanwhile, we never saw the waitress again, literally never came back to check on us, apologize, or ask if we needed anything. she was on her cell phone walking around, picking up tables, and bringing out waters on her cell phone talking! while working! we ate quickly, paid, and left. didn't leave tip, it was horrible service, cook brought out food and that was it, not once did anyone come ask if we needed anything, not even the check. my husband walked up to the register and paid. now i'm not a super confrontational person and i wish i got better with it and grow a pair of balls and should of made a scene, but i didn't, quit frankly i don't know what to do now, call the department of health services? i suppose, but this place lacks a lot of customer service and cleanliness. i will try to follow up with this to see if i hear from a manger until then.guys there are tons of asian cuisine.pick another location, but do not i sincerely say.do not waste your money and take a chance of getting sick.

no food for us, so i guess this is an anti review. ordered for pickup via the yelp app, got a confirmation, drive down there to be told system down, no order. rude and unhelpful. that was it. no offer to seat us, no offer to make an order quick, just turned away. we used to love lao sze chuan, but this experience, wildly varying quality from trip to trip, tony's tax fraud conviction and the fact that there are now hundreds of better chinese restaurants in chicago combine to make this our last trip. too bad. they used to be great.
enjoyed the house special beef szechwan style! i never tried a flavor like this over white ricei love the spiciness of the dishes. the spicier the better.

if i had an option of choosing zero stars i would. first of all i never write yelp reviews unless the restaurant was spectacular or completely awful. in this case it was awful! the food is not the greatest and definitely not worth the cost. you are better off going to panda express because it is more flavorful and the price is half the cost. i ordered the governors chicken and it was mostly the dough they cover the chicken with before they fry it. so in essence you order about 75% dough to 25% chicken. my friends ordered other items and it was just as bad. the food was not intolerable but it was definitely not worth the price. what made it one of the worst restaurant experiences in my life and definitely off my list was the service or should i say lack of service. our server was not fluent in english and that is not a problem for me, however every time we tried to get her attention or ask her for something she would cut us off and run off to some other table. we tried to get other waiters attention and they were just as rude. when it came to paying, we wanted to pay for what each of us ordered which was only one item per person since the price for some items were significantly different in price. it was only four of us with one item each so it would not have been hard. our waiter of course kept ignoring us so we ask another waiter to split it, who then told us to go up to the cashier and do it. we went up there trying to pay and the cashier kept ignoring is and only talking to the waiters. a waiter came to us and told us to go back and sit down who at this point our initial waiter was cleaning the table and was practically cleaning over us and bumping into us without apologizing. in essence do not go here unless you want mediocre food and terrible service from waiters who ignore you and clean over you as if you are not there!
really good food! service not so much. no cookies of fortune and you pay for the rice.

tony's dry chili chicken, spicy ma po tofu, spicy string beans and spicy wontons are the reason that we eat here. service is always good. this is one of my favorite places for spicy chinese food in town.
love the mapo tofu, it is just perfect. this is the best place to eat in china town. we've visited a few times and it is consistently great!

the food is really good, but the service can be hit or miss. there is often a wait, which is uncommon for chinatown, but overall worth the wait. the garlic chinese broccoli is my favorite! the vegetarian dishes are the most impressive here.

we were told by our hotel that this was the best chinese in the area. when we got there we were seated quickly and all our food came out pretty quickly! everything was delicious and i loved everything we ate. the pork dumplings were the best part of the meal because of how tastey they were! i would highly recommend them to anyone who comes here. loved the food and the service!

came here because bf loves mapo tofu. we ordered the mapo tofu, dry chili chicken, string beans, and lemon shrimp. surprisingly my least fav is the mapo tofu. the dry chili chicked and shrimp are so so so good!

came back for a second round of szechuan goodness and i am happy that i did! i tried more items with my friend from out of town, and we were loving the flavors that came with each bite. bean curd home style (11.95) spicy spicy tofu that's not the simple ma po style. the pieces of bean curd were gigantic and we were definitely unable to finish such a large plate. chef dry chili chicken (12.45) loaded with chili peppers and a dry rub seasoning, these pieces of chicken were fire. by the end of it, we could take home the plate of chili seasoning and made a new saute with all the magnificent flavors from this dish. fried rice cakes with shrimp (8.95) i love me some flat rice cakes shanghai style. it was definitely on the saucier side so i recommend getting some white rice to help counterbalance the flavors. all in all, still a very good restaurant here in the heart of chicago's chinatown. service continues to be a bit slow, but you just need to be assertive in flagging someone down if you need anything.

horrible service , we ordered ma po tofu mild spicy and it came out fully loaded with chili. i took a bite and almost cried, i complain to the server that this is a lot spicy then i ordered. he start argue with me says it is already mild. will never come back again and was so disappointed.
i enjoyed the spicy dry chicken and garlic egg plant. will be back for the chicken dish for sure.

i've stayed @ chicago for a long time. this place where is the first time i've been heard that rice doesnt come with meal! i've been to lao szechuan so many times, and none of them charged rice until last weekend. fine! i compromised! if they did so, at least meal should be authentic, but truth was not! they should have had free appetizer which was pickle cabbage, but they didn't. boil beef was no cilantro, ground red pepper, and seed powder upon it, and the dish was way too hot! meanwhile, the napa and beef in dish was a little bit sour! i couldn't believe they did such bullshit! fishy flavored eggplant was way too oily, which made my wife was uncomfortable real bad. spicy rabbit tasted grassy, they didn't even know how to cover that smell from rabbits! also, the dish was not worthy that price! moreover, even though dish was not authentic, i would have expected fine service, but totally opposite! waitress were rude and miscommunicated! the only way to call them was to sway a credit card! for respect, i still tipped them 2 dollars which less than 10% at dinner time, because i didn't think they were worthy to be tipped over 18%. overall, i highly don't recommend people to go there, unless you are willing to spend money for nothing satisfied!

i expected to have some authentic chinese at this place since its one of the good restaurants in chinatown. their staff was so rude, they do not understand english. its really difficult to communicate with them. the food was too oily, i have had better chinese food at other places. i definitely do not recommend this place its a big disappointment.

this place sucks. it is far from the best chinese, and they charge you for rice. shouldn't rice be included as part of the meal? also, they ran out of forks. we repeatedly asked for forks, no one brought any, i walked up to counter, and they asked me to return to my table even though i pointed out no one had brought us forks. the food is also bland. with so many other options available, please seek them. (i know how to use chopsticks for those who try to call me out. but we had to be back at conference asap, so we didn't have time to pick up grains of rice.)

worst service. .they charged my credit card the night that we had dinner and 3 days later! !.my 80 dls meal became a 160 dls meal! !.i called them to try to figure out the erroneous charge and the lady that answered their phone refused to provide any assistance, as i explained to her the issue she would walk away from the phone, take other orders, charge other customers, and left me hanging. .the food is not worth the issues. .my other problem is why did they keep my credit card information! horrible place that makes you wonder about their integrity!

this was our favorite restaurant until one day my boyfriend found a hair from their food. they get it back then return us a warm but not hot food, obviously they just take it back and remove the hair and give us back. secondly, you will always wonder how could a restaurant has wonderful food but awful service? they don't have enough servers so we always have to sit there wait a long time and have nobody to serve us. today, i order food delivery, the lady who picked up the phone was very very rude, i try to repeat my phone number but she said ok ok i get it ok bye. after one hour i call back to see how long i need to wait, she screamed something in the phone and put my aside. i clearly could hear she talked to another guy in another phone in chinese said you could charge her one or two dollar for her rice. excuse me? i'm glad that i understand chinese so i know she tried to charge me more for rice? that lady i know her, short her, very rude all the time. a lady with long hair and a skinny tall guy are very very friendly though. plus, don't go to their bathroom, disgusting!

my family had a really tiring day and we decided to stop by here to get some authentic chinese food. we were really disappointed by the service. first it was very delayed and food we got was cold. we were charged extra for substituting meats (though we were not informed). also, since we payed in cash, the change we got back was not the right amount. in all it was not a very good experience and i will have to think at least 10 times before coming back.

this restaurant has the worst and most terrible customer service! my group of 6 friends came to lao sze chuan for a late dinner on saturday night. coming from a 5 hour drive from michigan, we head to chinatown. exhausted, starving and craving for a hot, steamy bowl of beef noodle soup. since i have been to lao sze chuan a couple of times and i love their overly delicious dry chili chicken and after asking tomy if they have the beef noodle soup we want in the menu, we decided to eat here. and so my friend and i ordered the spicy beef stew noodle soup! it is the greasiest and most disgusting noodle soup i have had my entire life! you can literally see the grease on top of the bowl. it made us sick! it tasted like they poured a handful of msg! it tasted very strange and the flavor did not come off even after drinking so much water. i literally just ate one bite of it. so of course we had to complain. i tried to address my concern to the manager on duty tomy, who came out to smoke at least 3x for half an hour we were there. instead of being courteous, tomy rudely address our concern with his saliva spitting all over the place, yelling how can i change it? you already ate the beef! then he left! i mean really? my bowl was full and i had literally one spoon of the soup! how in the world would i know how it taste like with o tasting it! and to get water refills, you literally have to come to the servers at the counter to ask for it. a big mistake to decide to eat here! with some of the award winning food being delicious but with awful customer service, this place does not deserve a single star. go to minghin next door if you want to have great food and be treated politely and courteously.

the servers thought i was chinese so they greeted me with a smile until i said i wasn't. she then said just sit there, i was seated and the greeter threw the menu at the table and just walked away. i waited 15 minutes to get my water and another 15 minutes to order. the menu has no explanation about the food except the dish's name. a different server came and took my order (he was nice). the food came out quickly, but i'm giving this restaurant a 1 star due to the customer service and how improper the restaurant was. the servers started preparing string beans in front of the customers and they never came to check how the food was. i also had to wait forever to get my check even though i had asked.

the review depends on which of his restaurants you visit. if you go to the lao szechaun in nordstrom's building then a 4 star meal is in order. been there several times and have had great food. house special hot and sour soup is off the charts spicy and great for chili heads. also the dry chili chicken is exceptional. the problem was after having a couple great lunches we decided to visit the original in chinatown. now if you want authentic chinese hot pot and already understand what that means then head on down, but for the uninitiated hang on too your seats. we ordered the traditional hot pot, if service was better like downtown then we should have been told to stay on the american side of menu. first out came the two side pot one side spicy the other not then out came the tray of items to cook into the broth. the tray included tripe, chicken feet, tofu, stinky tofu, fish ball (their term), pig ball ( not sure if this is ground up or a testicle), shrimp with head on, some type of fish that looked like it had been defrosted on sidewalk out back, muscles that came to table raw and smelly ( not in the fresh sea good way). at this point i felt like they were back in the kitchen laughing at us. well we decide to try the authentic.spicey broth was only option for me other was not good. i like menudo so i tried the tripe, not a good first choice. not sure what fish ball was and maybe i don't want to. my friends kept asking if this was some kind of prank i was playing on them. also when the check came i was told i am no longer allowed to pick the restaurant.

i don't understand the great reviews about the dry chili chicken. it tastes like greasy, salty pork rinds. and the service sucked too. the hostess tried to sit me at a table that was filthy and had a stroller behind it. the entire time i was there they did not attempt to seat anyone else there. it took 12 minutes and some eye contact for someone to take my order. and the waitress never came back with my water. this place must have been good back in the day bit as o 07/09/2016 it it was horrible. disappointed

exceptional food. we're tourists from florida and frequent one of the best chinese restaurants in florida often. this was the first restaurant we've been to in any city that best it. rich flavors, lots of options and authentic ingredients imported from china. when we arrived an extroverted manager greeted us decked out in gold. he quickly informed us there was going to be a wait but told us it was worth it. we waited and were sat about 30 minutes later. we ordered a lot to sample different dishes including: kung po chicken, orange chicken, spring rolls, crab rangoon assorted soups and fried dumplings. all were great. service was slow, but they were very busy. we will go back again the next time we're in chicago.
food is fantastic (expect a rush because of this), service is also friendly. my only complaint is that the plastic chairs they use can be a bit uncomfortable at times.

food is ok, service is horrible. we would have tried more items but out server never came back. they didn't even bring us rice until we had to flag someone done halfway through the meal. never refilled our water and waited forever for the check.

authentic, delicious si chuan cuisine. service is not the important factor here (service has never been a strength of asian restaurants) but the food is wonderful. shui zhu yu: fish in spicy sauce/broth. this came in the typical bright red broth chock full of crushed red chili, with a half inch of oil on top. the fish was tender and the flavor was perfect! liang fen: this is crazy spicy.newcomers beware. good flavor if you can handle it! dan dan mian: awesome awesome flavor and deliciously chewy noodles. highly recommend! this is a wonderful place to try this regional chinese food!

ordered spicy duck tongue, only a little portion of duck tongue, lots of chili peppers, not worth 16.00.the duck tongue is not even fresh, which made my stomach hurts. it is not the good restaurant i went to many years ago.just became worse.
best chinno food i ever had in my life! fast food, the guy with all the jade jewelry is funny and the man!
surprisingly good. i really liked the atmosphere and layout when i walked in and the food was amazing. one of my favorite spots to go and will continue going
great location, authentic chinese food. check it out if you like spicy food, and you actually know what authentic chinese food is like. no need to come here if you only order orange chicken.
really spicy but tasty food. the spicy chicken was just dynamite. not for the faint of heart.

sweet and sour shrimp, potstickers, spring rolls, szechwan green beans, chicken fried rice, and kung pao chicken were all delicious. small list of beer and wine options but they have a byob option with a 10 corkage fee. with a big group, the tables with the lazy susans are perfect! we were able to share with ease.

for such a shady operation, the food is still pretty good. service can be lackluster but what do you expect, it's a chinese restaurant! the waiters are hard to flag down and some only speak chinese so bring a friend to help you if you don't speak mandarin! they're very good at accommodating for large groups as well. dry chili chicken i mean the dish is half chilis but the half that is chicken is delectable; my friends and i always order at least 2 of these when we come here (boys eat a lot!). chicken is crisp but not overly oily garlic eggplant whenever i go to a chinese restaurant i must order this; without fail it is delicious here mapo tofu it's spicy so be careful! it's a little too oily for my taste though so i try to wipe it all off on my plate before i eat it green beans standard fare note: they validate your parking! if you park in the lot, you end up only paying 2, just don't forget to ask them before you leave the restaurant!
my fav spot in chinatown. i love the ma po tofu, fish fillet, and crispy mayo shrimp. they have a good selection of spicy dishes. great authentic taste!

we ordered caigen tofu, green pepper eggplant, tiger skin fried pepper, mala douhua. da loves the tofu. we both think eggplant is good. fried pepper is just so so. douhua is very ma and good! the free preserved cabbage is very good. a glass of cold water is a must. ;)

i would give this place 3.5 stars. we came here on a busy saturday afternoon. the service was rushed and our server seemed indifferent. she did not speak english and it seemed to me that she thought it was our job to speak chinese. the place looked clean but it had the ambience of a high school cafeteria. i went here with a friend who insisted that we have their crispy shrimp. i've had crispy shrimp before but their version is one of the best. we also had eggplant in brown sauce which was tender and tasty. these are two of my favorite chinese dishes so i was glad to be able to get them in one restaurant. the prices were good and the portions were large which i'm used to having in a chinese restaurant. i do plan to come back and check out their rather extensive menu and see if their other dishes taste as good. there are several lao sze chuan restaurants in chicago but this one is located in chinatown square in the north part of chinatown. it's a touristy but still cool outdoor mall with dozens of little shops and bakeries. you can eat here and then wander through the mall to do some shopping or stop in at one of the bakeries to get something to nosh on when you walk around. for all i know you can pop in someplace for an acupuncture treatment while you meander through. there is a parking lot across the street.
food here has generally gotten worse over time. would have recommended as a place to eat in chicago a few years ago, but now it is average at best.

let me start out by saying lao sze chuan is the best chinese restaurant i have ever been to, i have been here multiple multiple times over the years and tons of other chinese restaurants as well but none really could match the flavor of the dishes here, from the dry chili chicken to the mongolian beef, to the szechuan spicy beef everything here is almost perfect taste wise, do yourself a favor if you come here don't order cantonese don't order fried rice or beef chop suey if you want that go to 3 happiness down the street or your local hole in the wall around the corner, this place specializes in spicy dishes get the dry chili chicken this is the best dish here and depending on the chef will set your mouth on fire and make you sweat all worth it, you could ask for dishes less spicy if you're not accustomed to spicy food, szechuan spicy beef is also delicious big old bowl of pepper cabbage and beef so bomb! get the orange beef if you want a cantonese dish this is very very good and not too spicy at all, spring rolls are very good they don't have regular egg rolls here so don't even try it, another good appetizer here are the szechuan dumplings yummy, any spicy dish is good here kung pao, hunan etc. shrimps are big not scampy, never tried the hot pot here looks really good but i don't know why i have never tried it supposed to be a specialty here, now i deduct a star for a reason, the service is horrible, and i mean horrible they don't come back they bring you your dinner before your appetizer, they don't bring you the check they don't give you water unless you ask they don't give you a refill, sometimes they run out of rice, ( run out of rice! ) had a real bad experience here one time when they were down to one chef and it took forever for us to get all our food, i was ready to walk out luckily my family convinced me to stay, but i keep coming back luckily a lot of the staff know us so we tend to get better service than other people but still sometimes it's the same old lao szechuan, still i keep coming back and i'm not the only one this place has been closed down twice reopens every time people know about it and they still pack the place, it's really simple food is so damn good service is so damn bad gets closed down reopens, people come back i come back place is so damn good lol!

rude. and more so than what you're used to at a chinese restaurant. placed a pick up order and after 20 minutes came in. waited and asked about our order. it's not ready yet. the same guy who said that never showed again. waited 15 minutes. asked a lady now about the order. not ready yet. it will be there. and gestures to a cart next to us. now that we have stood around in the restaurant, waiting, with no update and being ignored, we call eat24 who confirms the restaurant is open, but non responsive and cancels our order. thanks, eat24! we decided to head down a few doors to chi cafe. too many chinese spots in chinatown. never again, lao.

having had a decent amount of sichuan food in my life (my family is from sichuan), this place is a miss. we ordered several dishes including duck, eggplant, cumin lamb and rice noodles. the eggplant was super oily and the rice noodles were flavorless. the duck and cumin lamb were decent, but overall the food at this place is overhyped. most importantly, the service was severely lacking. i'm used to gruff service especially in chinatown, but this was on another level. we had to ask several times just to get water and were blatantly ignored twice when we said we were ready to order. mediocre food + terrible service = ignore. you're better off checking out chengdu expression up north.

the food here is authentic and very delicious. the menu is extensive, so if you're indecisive like myself, you will have a hard time figuring out what to order! it would help if there were mini captions after each item to make it easier for ordering purposes. nonetheless, i'm sure anything you order wouldn't be a disappointment! i went here with three friends after a white sox game on a sunday evening, so it was pretty busy. we beat most of the foot traffic, and were lucky to be seated right away as there was a line out of the door while we were indulging in our dishes. the only reason why i'm giving this place 3 stars is because the staff was impolite with us even though the service was fast.

this place gets 3 stars because the food is great. however the service was terrible. we got forced out of our seats by a guy who just waved us to another table, our appetizer came out after our main dish, we had to ask 3 different people for our white rice which came out towards the end of our meal, and we never got more than our first serving of water. i still tipped well and recommend the food but please work on the service. it wasn't even that busy!

terrible service. 4 of us ordered meal, only 3 came out. i asked our waitresses were my meal was and she brought an empty plate. after everyone was done my meal finally came out. then it was not even what i ordered and they argued about. not very good, over rated.

nothing like a legit authentic chinese restaurant in a chinatown! the food was fantastic. only one other chinese restaurant that i remember can match this place when it comes to food. we are a group of 7 and we ordered chengdu dumplings, don don noodles, combination pan fried noodles, eggplant with pork, mongolian beef, mongolian lamb, mongolian chicken, and lobster with ginger scallion sauce. everything tasted amazing! the service, however, was a little disappointing. it was a friday night and they were extremely busy, so i can understand to a point. but they didn't check on us very often and while everyone was very polite and friendly when they did check on us, it was just very hard to get their attention when we needed something. and when we would ask for things like more napkins, more tea, or a fork, they seemed to do 10 other things before bringing them to us. most of the staff did not speak english very well, which made communication difficult. there was one gentleman, however, who was very helpful. he seemed to be a manager and took very good care of us. one final thought when we ordered the lobster, we were told it was taking a little longer than everything else because they had to go buy it from the market. extra points for freshness, but minus points for the long wait. it did come while we were still eating, though, so it wasn't a huge deal. i would come back here again if i'm in the area because the food is that delicious! but i will have to make sure i have plenty of time and patience when i do.

located in china town market, 2nd time being there and it was a good experience. the restaurant had a wait of about 45 mins according to the host but we were seating after 20 mins of waiting. the food was out really quick and was delicious. i warn you, for a person who loves spicy food, their spicy sauce is hot! authentic food and delicious.

i've always been a fan of lao both locations (river north and chinatown) are distinct yet equally good. the chinatown location has hot appetizers, serves a delicious spicy cabbage on the house, and has great portion sizes. on weekends, there's usually a crowd here with good reason. one complaint would be that on occasion, the mapo tofu is a little too tongue numbingly spicy, but otherwise, i've always enjoyed my experience here.

we four girls ordered four dishes. waiter served a small bowl of rice. and finally they charged us total 4 (1 per person). they charged without consent!generally, chinese restaurant does not charge for rice. if they charge, should let customers know!

service has improved, compared to when this restaurant first opened, when the caucasian waitress with a european accent knew absolutely about chinese food. the food is in general tasty. but the tables are stlll ridiculously small, and not suitable for chinese dining.

this review is based solely on the food, which was not great, but not awful. since so many people seem to love this place, i though the food would be a lot better than it was. that's not to say that i will never eat here again, but it won't be my first choice for chinese food.

fantastic chinese food that is a bit more on the chinese side than your average american fake chinese food restaurant. their dry chili chick is absolutely killer, in both ways. i always get it, and i always need constant refills of water, and my stomach always protests an hour later. but it is awesome.

i would have given this place a 4 star until my last incidence. i love their red hot chili chicken entree and most of their other dishes. this place gives more chicken compared to the one on michigan ave. i didn't think they had bad food until my last order. i ordered the red hot chili chicken and they gave me a wrong order. i didn't check the food until i went home and then it was too much work to go back and exchange it. they gave me a dish that was sweet fried chicken. the taste was so awful. i couldn't eat it.

my favorite place in chinatown. if you like szechuan spicy, this is the spot. chef's special dry chili chicken is off the hook, and they have great hotpot here too. not everything is spicey so dont freak out, there are 980 items on the menu! i've searched the country for szechuan food like this and nothing comes close, not in new york, not in san francisco. this is a must. super friendly staff and great service. i don't recommend the lao szechuan up in uptown chicago, but this location in chinatown is the one to go to.
the food is good, but the service is not. my husband ordered a diet coke. they never brought it, and they actually charged us for that until we noticed them. bad attention.

they are used to be great.just came here for hot pot and boy they were mediocre at best. the ingredients looked very poorly presented and were not good quality. the broth used to be a lot more flavorful, now they were not as fragrant. the spicy broth had tons of peppercorns and that was all i tasted. sadly i just x ed this place from our chicago must eat list.
i would like to eat here again, the food was delicious. our group ordered the spicy garlic eggplant and dry chicken chili. very good dishes eager to try more items from their menu.

even though i've lived on the south side for almost 3 years now, i had never been to chinatown until friday, when i found myself at lao szechuan. now, i can't wait to go back! service was lightning quick, if a bit spotty (we only got 2 water glasses for a table of 7). other than that, the food came very quickly once we ordered. we shared szechuan green beans (delicious and garlicky), 9 story pagoda chicken, pork fried noodles, szechuan beef, and some pork dumplings in a spicy chili sauce. everything was tasty, and it made my first trip to chinatown memorable and delicious.

pros: great food. red spice chicken, and the curry fish were my favorite. the potstickers are definitely worth it (though on a health adjusted basis are iffy). cons: the quality of the red spice chicken varies from day to day.
my favorite chinese place in chicago. i always go with a group and we get several dishes to share. the dry chili chicken is a must have!

gross. everything we ordered tastes like freezer burn. chili chicken was totally dried out and tasted like an old refrigerator. mu shoo pancakes were all dried and cracked. very disappointing 60 delivery.

i came here with a group of friends. one of them being my classmate who is actually from beijing china! he ordered for us and picked the fried pork with green onions, soft tofu, governor's chicken, and garlic spinach. my favorite was the garlic spinach and governor's chicken. the governor's chicken reminds me of a spicy sweet and sour chicken. the chicken is breaded, with green bell peppers, onion, and spicy peppers in a sweet sauce. this was my first time here and i really enjoyed the spot. keep in mind that the region where the food comes from (sze chuan) cooks a lot with spices and peppers. i was told that this region highly believe in spices and peppers in their dishes. if you order the item not spicy, you may lose out on the essence of the dish, as the dishes are made with the intention to be spicy. i also asked my classmate if the food was very similar to the food in china and he said it tastes very very similar to food in that region! tip: if you pay in cash you can ask for 10% off!

this place looks a little basic. they have plastic chairs and easy simple tables. i did like the food a lot though, it's close to sichuan food. i tried the chefs special dry spicy chicken, the don don noodles and the fried bread with condensed milk. the last one was a little disappointing, the others were good. the chicken was crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside, well made. i wouldn't say the food was outstanding but this is a good solid option for some sichuan food if you are in chinatown. i got free tea and kimchi with my order and the service was good, helpful waiters.
the food was amazing, tried chinese beer for the first time and i loved it. the service is not the greatest but definitely have to come back to try out new food. the kung pao scallop are delicious

my first visit to chinatown may be my last. i've had chinese food all over the world and expected pretty good food in chinatown, but boy was i disappointed. there were 8 of us, so we had a lot of selections and none were comparable in quality to what we get outside chinatown. the best i can say about this place is that the food was edible and i did not get sick, beyond that, nothing. yech. and that is without mentioning the non existent service.

i live on mary st. in bridgeport. i usually order 5 extra prawns. our daughter has become hooked in the sesame chicken. everyone has been polite when i make pickups occasionally so this place is one i would always recommend.

good stuff, not the best, but great for the price. it's a bit cheap of an environment (the one in chinatown), and kind of creepy when it's not busy, but i wasn't disappointed. next time i might order something a but pricier on the menu just to see what they've got for the big spenders!
i ordered takeout. i love eating here. i honestly love eating here, but this is the second time i've gotten food poisoning.

its been a few years i went to lao sze chuan, but i distinctly remember the chili chicken. it's still as good. the only issue here is service. it pretty much sucks and you immediately get a feeling that the staff don't really care if you have a pleasant experience. it's shocking to see that the restaurant operates without anyone speaking fluent english. oh well as long as i get some good chilli chicken!
the service is great. all the waiters and waitresses are prompt, polite and helpful. the food is okay and tailored to americans' taste not authentic sichun (si chuan ).
the food and service were really great, it was just abit too spicy for my tastes. however i left full and satisfied.

i have eaten at this restaurant and ordered for delivery many times, mostly because it is a few blocks from my apartment. never again. like other reviewers, i have to agree that the service is awful. vegetarians are left waiting until the meat eaters have finished their meals before getting their dishes, even when the server is alerted to the issue; the food is often cold and the sauces, rather than silky, are gelatinous. most often, the moo shoo pancakes are stuck to each other and inseparable. the duck is a waste of money as most of it remains uncarved and taken back to the kitchen as trash. delivery is a problem and the restaurant staff lie constantly about where your order is. they oftentimes get the order wrong and then charge you anyway. the manager has an awfully arrogant attitude for a restaurant that can't deliver on its promise of authentic chinese food. this is a tourist trap. not far from this restaurant is ming hin try it; it is more reasonably priced; has better food; and no bad attitude.

they wouldn't redeem their yelp check in offer. they seemed upset that i would even suggest it. why would you offer a check in offer if don't want people to use it? horrible customer service! the food is also nothing special.

i catered my husband's birthday party through lao sze chuan amazing! it was one of the only chinese restaurants i could find that offered party size catering. what a fun night with friends enjoying orange chicken, shrimp lo mein, vegetable fried rice and crab rangoon out of complimentary takeout containers, while looking at art in a gallery! alex was so professional. confirmed everything the day of so i didn't have to worry, and offered me great group rates. definitely consider lao sze chuan for your next party!
the location is great with real chinese taste food. not only sichuan food but also beijing, shanghai food is available!
this was recommended to us by a local and i'm so glad we went. lots of spicy options and the dumplings were to die for. service took a little longer than we hoped so be prepared to wait.

spicy chinese food in the city! rolled in here on a cold rainy day to warm up. the boiled beef was excellent very spicy and their ma po tofu was also very good to have. very small location but they do a good job with the service as well

we went on a non busy snow day started with the egg roll and crab rangoons. both delish. the flavor of the egg rolls were so good. crab rangoons were thick and tasty. onto mongolian beef and eggplant in garlic sauce.it was perfect. i've eaten so much chinese food throughout the us but by far the best i've had. great flavors. the wait staff was very nice. i would go back again and again.

by far my favorite chinese food in chicago. and i've eaten a lot. i won't disagree that the ambience is not the best. the service gets a little busy and the place is a little old and drabby. the food is ridiculously good! everything i've eaten here has been off the charts. no matter the busyness the staff is all very sweet and tries to make you comfortable. the ma po tofu is unbelievable and the house fried noodles are the perfect accompaniment. the spice level on everything is made to taste and the authentic flavors can't be beat.

the only reason why i don't give a zero is cause i can't. this restaurant does not provide authentic chinese food or sichuan food. i do not agree that this is the best chinese restaurant in us. in addition, the waiters forgot our menus and failed to present the dishes in time. we regretted to go to that restaurant.

this place calls itself the best chinese restaurant in the usa. not so much. definitely not the worst, by any means, but the best? no way. don't get me wrong; we didn't have any major issues with our food. my spicy food loving friend was happy with the spice in the boiled beef. my mongolian tenderloin was nice and tender. my daughter was good with her orange chicken. the spring rolls were fine (used the yelp check in freebie). however, nothing was overly flavorful, blew us away, or was any better than what our local chinese restaurants have to offer back home. the servers seemed overwhelmed and had a difficult time keeping up. one brought a dish out to a couple just as they gave up on it and were about to leave. another group next to us ordered additional food and the server forgot all about it. i wouldn't tell anyone not to go, but don't expect to be amazed.

i'm never disappointed when i come here. it's in a good location and parking is not impossible in chinatown. the place is cozy. the dining room is always full, but you always have your space. their ma po tofu is unique tasting and very delicious, as are the szechuan green beans. the hot pots are always a good choice. make sure to drink up the house tea to keep your stomach settled!

first time here. wait was worth it! great appetizers and entrees! atmosphere was lively. but tommy, the greeter and jack of all trades, was the man! expect a wait but expect a good meal as your reward!

terrible stay home. currently been waiting for almost an hour and a half at the table. table is greasey and bathrooms are disgusting. water at table is disgusting/funky, egg rolls are cold in the middle. still waiting for meal. never again!

note: i've been here twice. i can't remember the first time well because i was with a big group and the food was not the center of attention, but i think i was satisfied. this post addresses the second time, when i had a terrible experience. i added an extra star to reflect an average of these two occasions. my family went to this restaurant some time ago and we were quite disappointed. the food was ok to mediocre, but service was extremely poor. i rarely reduce my rating for service unless it is noticeably bad, but this was one of those exceptional cases. i think that because we went during a long weekend, the customer volume was high and the waiters were over worked. one of the guys looked like he already swore to leave the labor force forever once his shift was over. while busy season is not really an excuse for a restaurant to ignore service quality, i did cut them some slack. the first problem was our soup. we got a pickled cabbage soup, but a few minutes later, the waiter came out with a spinach soup, saying that there was no more cabbage soup and proceeded to convince us that there was not much difference between the two anyhow. of course, you don't need to know anything about chinese cuisine to figure out that this persuasion was doomed to fail, and we refused the soup altogether. next we got a braised chicken dish that we never ordered. we got to keep it i always love free food but i had to imagine that some other group was going to become very upset. our snow pea leaves then came and they didn't look right. usually, they are dark green and leafy, but these were light green and consisted purely of stems that were hard to chew. if you search snow pea leaves on google, you'll see pictures of this beautiful, luscious dish, mmmmm. but we were not granted this pleasure. they were nearly inedible (my chinese parents then said something about the ambiguity of the word dou miao (dou miao) that could have caused this discrepancy, but i barely know the language; please don't judge if you speak fluent mandarin). the one other dish we ordered was nothing remarkable, but it was correct. i don't want to write any lies, and so will not try to name the dish. besides that, the second floor seating area (which is more of an annex, for when the first floor area is filled) has no foyer, so every time someone enters the restaurant, you'll be greeted with a blast of air. in the winter, beware. at least ask to sit away from the entrance if possible. it was in the low 30s and blustery when we went, so you can imagine how pleased we were to get that free air conditioning in the wrong season.
